# UNCF: A Big American Idea that Became a Reality THE 76TH NATIONAL UNCF “A MIND IS…” GALA WAS MADE POSSIBLE BY MAJOR SPONSORS AND PARTNERS LIKE PROCTER AND GAMBLE, WHICH RECEIVED THE UNCF KEEPERS OF THE FLAME LEGACY AWARD. PICTURED (FROM L TO R) ARE BARRON WITHERSPOON, DAVID TAYLOR, TAMARA THOMAS, MONICA TURNER, DR. MICHAEL L. LOMAX, SHELLY MCNAMARA, PAUL GAMA, AMY ROBERTI, CRYSTAL HARRELL AND TERENCE MOORE. 

SPEAKER OF THE U.S. HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES NANCY PELOSI ATTENDED THE NATIONAL UNCF “A MIND IS…” GALA IN HONOR OF HER COLLEAGUES U.S. REP. JOHN LEWIS (D-GA) AND U.S. REP. JAMES CLYBURNE (D-SC), WHO BOTH RECEIVED THE UNCF FREDERICK D. PATTERSON AWARD DURING THE EVENT. DURING THE CELEBRATION, DR. MICHAEL LOMAX ANNOUNCED THE RETIREMENT OF RUST COLLEGE PRESIDENT DR. DAVID L. BECKLEY, WHO LEFT HIS POST AFTER 26 YEARS AT THE TOP OF THE HOLLY SPRINGS, MS, INSTITUTION. 

THE UNCF FREDERICK D. PATTERSON AWARD WAS PRESENTED TO U.S. REP JAMES CLYBURNE (D-SC) AND U.S. REP. JOHN LEWIS (D-GA) FOR THEIR CONTRIBUTIONS TO HIGHER EDUCATION AND CIVIL RIGHTS. ACCEPTING ON THEIR BEHALF WERE MIGNON CLYBURNE, REP. CLYBURNE’S DAUGHTER, AND U.S. REP. ANDRÉ CARSON (D-IN). ALSO ON STAGE (FROM LEFT TO RIGHT) WERE DR. MICHAEL LOMAX, UNCF BOARD MEMBER MILTON H. JONES JR., SPEAKER NANCY PELOSI, UNCF BOARD MEMBER AND TALLADEGA COLLEGE PRESIDENT BILLY HAWKINS, FORMER FISK UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT DR. KEVIN ROME AND SHAW UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT DR. PAULETTE DILLARD. W hen Dr. Frederick D. Patterson, Mary McLeod Bethune, John D. Rockefeller and other legendary American education, business and social leaders came together in 1944 in New York City to incorporate the United Negro College Fund in April 1944, their vision was to fuel historically Black colleges and universities (HBCUs) across the United States far into the future—all the while not knowing how long the mission would last or how many lives it would touch. Originally, UNCF supported 27 colleges. The goal was simple—make it easier for the smaller, underfunded HBCUs to continue to educate a largely Black constituency that had few to no other college options because African American contributions to American society were sorely needed— and at all levels. And UNCF was a success from the very beginning. The �rst annual campaign in 1944 raised $765,000—an amount three times more than what was raised by the individual colleges through separate fundraising campaigns in the previous year. In their wildest dreams, UNCF’s founders could not have foreseen the success of this fundamentally big American idea that became a reality. In 2019, UNCF—having stood the test of time—turned 75. Since those heady early days, many things have changed. From 27 member institutions to 37. From a few thousand students annually attending its HBCUs to 55,000. Add to that, an additional 5,000-plus students who get scholarships who aren’t attending UNCF-member HBCUs, and UNCF annually supports more than 60,000 students in total. 

> YOUNG MEN FROM THE KIPP DC – COLLEGE PREPARATORY ACADEMY PUBLIC CHARTER SCHOOL GAVE A SPECIAL LIVE PERFORMANCE FROM THE BROADWAY PLAY, “NEWSIES,” DURING THE 76TH NATIONAL UNCF “A MIND IS…” GALA.

To commemorate the year, UNCF launched a series of 75th anniversary events all year long, raising awareness about how it has worked tirelessly to enable as many students to get to and through college as possible. UNCF conducted 63 events, raising an unprecedented $14 million in unrestricted revenue. That amounts to more than 8,000 students earning their degrees during the most recent academic year. Remarkable, one might say. But it doesn’t end there. In its 75 years, UNCF has raised over $5 billion in donations—gifts—from supporters, both large and small, across the spectrum of the United States. And through those billions of gifted dollars, it has helped more than half a million students earn their college degrees. Quite an accomplishment—and quite a reason to come together to celebrate. So, on March 5, 2020, UNCF o�cially wrapped up its 75th anniversary celebration e�orts during its National “A Mind Is…” Gala, in Washington, DC, at the Wardman Park Marriott Hotel, recognizing all that has been and launching a vision of what is yet to come. Among the many tributes and honorees supporting UNCF over its decades of work were the Top Ladies of Distinction, Procter and Gamble and Lilly Endowment, Inc. Also marking the event were two signi�cant tributes to national civil rights leaders and federal lawmakers, U.S. Rep. John Lewis (D-GA) and U.S. Rep. James Clyburn (D-SC). Speaker of the House of Representatives Nancy Pelosi attended the event, showing her respect for both UNCF and the honorees. “It is a great honor to join the friends and leaders of UNCF to recognize two of our nation’s most extraordinary civil rights champions, Whip James Clyburn and the Conscience of the Congress, Congressman John Lewis, in this year that marks 55 years since the march from Selma,” said Speaker Pelosi. “As we observe this milestone and celebrate 76 years of UNCF’s outstanding success, we must all recommit to the �ght to expanding opportunities and advancing justice for communities of color and for all Americans, and to building the more perfect union that generations of courageous Americans have sacri�ced to build.” To punctuate 75 years and the national commemoration, UNCF President and CEO Dr. Michael Lomax added his thoughts to the evening. “As the story goes, the great African American poet Langston Hughes—another HBCU graduate—was working as a busboy here at the Wardman Park Hotel when he was discovered in 1925 by poet Vachel Lindsay. “So you might say that it is poetic justice that 95 years later, an organization dedicated to educating African American poets—and teachers and scientists and businesspeople—would have raised more than $5 billion in 75 years, would have helped graduate more than 500,000 students, and would be awarding more than 10,000 scholarships a year worth $100 million. “And would be a powerful and laser-focused advocate for its 37 private HBCUs, and one of the nation’s most e�ective advocates for all HBCUs. “Or that taken in aggregate, HBCUs would become an economic engine generating almost $15 billion in annual economic impact, and $130 billion in lifetime earnings for each HBCU graduating class? “I think Langston Hughes would have been proud. And we hope that all of you are too.” So, with more than 75 years of remarkable history, accomplishments and impact under its belt, UNCF now leans into the future, knowing that it remains the vital, necessary higher education dynamo that began all those years ago as a big American idea—an idea that has stuck with us because it works, and it does what it says it will do: empower needy, deserving students to get and through college successfully.

Advance your career with a master's in computer engineering. This two-year graduate degree can lead to a new profession or a salary bump. Discover the right degree for you.

![Image 4](https://res.cloudinary.com/highereducation/images/f_auto,q_auto/g_face,c_fill,fl_lossy,q_auto:best,w_448,h_382/v1662734874/ComputerScience.org/GettyImages-1308903390/GettyImages-1308903390.jpg?_i=AA) Credit: Tom Werner / DigitalVision / Getty Images

![Image 5](https://res.cloudinary.com/highereducation/images/f_auto,q_auto/g_face,c_fill,fl_lossy,q_auto:best,w_448,h_382/v1662734874/ComputerScience.org/GettyImages-1308903390/GettyImages-1308903390.jpg?_i=AA) Credit: Tom Werner / DigitalVision / Getty Images

A computer engineering master's degree dives deep into computer hardware, software, networks, and architecture. Graduate study can open the doors to research work, and introduce you to professors and peers who are leaders in the field.

If you aspire to work with artificial intelligence or robotics, write or test software, build hardware, or develop systems, this degree can help you achieve your ambition.

It can also allow you to earn more money. [According to Payscale](https://www.payscale.com/research/US/Degree=Master_of_Science_(MS)%2C_Computer_Engineering_(CE)/Salary), people with a master's in computer engineering earned an average annual salary of $108,000 as of November 2023 — at least $12,000 more a year than those with a bachelor's degree in the field.

Explore the guide below to learn more about the top computer engineering master's degrees, including admissions requirements, career options, and answers to the most frequently asked questions.

Popular Online Programs
-----------------------

Learn about start dates, transferring credits, availability of financial aid, and more by contacting the universities below.

[](https://www.computerscience.org/degrees/masters/computer-engineering)
Top Computer Engineering Master's Programs
------------------------------------------

### How We Rank Colleges And Bootcamps

ComputerScience.org ranks computer science degree programs at the associate, bachelor’s, master’s, and doctoral levels. We also rank bootcamps and certificate programs. Our top priority is making sure you find the best possible fit for your education. We use up-to-date national statistics and focus on factors like return on investment, academic quality, and affordability.

Take a closer look at our rankings on [our rankings methodology page](https://www.computerscience.org/methodology/).

[](https://www.computerscience.org/degrees/masters/computer-engineering)
Why Get a Computer Engineering Master's Degree?
-----------------------------------------------

Computer engineering started in the 1940s when Dr. John Vincent Atanasoff, a professor at Iowa State College, and his student Clifford Berry built the first electronic digital computer. Formal computer engineering education, however, did not launch until 1971, when Case Western Reserve offered the first accredited computer engineering degree in the U.S.

Today, more than 78,000 computer hardware engineers work in research, development, and manufacturing settings across the U.S. In 2022, the [Bureau of Labor Statistics](https://www.bls.gov/ooh/architecture-and-engineering/computer-hardware-engineers.htm#tab-1) (BLS) projected that the field would add 3,600 new jobs by 2032. Hardware engineers earn a median annual wage of $132,360 — almost three times the median salary for all occupations.

Computer engineering professionals are building the world of tomorrow. A [computer engineering degree](https://www.computerscience.org/degrees/computer-engineering-programs/) can also prepare you for a career as a network architect, software engineer, information systems manager, or research scientist. These fast-growing, high-paying fields can provide meaningful and exciting work for problem-solvers and critical thinkers.

While a graduate certificate or bootcamp may be faster, a master's degree in computer engineering offers several benefits:

*   **Expand Your Knowledge Base**: If you work in technology design, you should be able to apply what you learn in a computer engineering master's degree right away. Your knowledge may help you be more effective in your current role or transition to a new career.
*   **Work in a Complex Subfield**: A master's program can help you qualify for math-intensive jobs, to work with autonomous machines, or do chip or register-transfer level design. A degree can also prepare you for a director or senior director role.
*   **Prepare for a Doctorate**: If you aspire to teach at the college level or perform original research in the field, you need a doctorate. A master's degree can equip you for next-level study.

What to Expect From Computer Engineering Graduate Programs
----------------------------------------------------------

As the world grows more digitized, employers, from hospitals to national security agencies, need innovative experts who can create groundbreaking technology to advance human flourishing.

Computer engineering graduate programs can help you learn how to build the smart devices that connect the modern world. As a student, you can learn about topics from [artificial intelligence](https://www.computerscience.org/resources/artificial-intelligence/) to cybersecurity, but your focus will rest on designing, scaling, and programming computer systems.

Earning a master's degree in this field usually takes two years if you enroll in 6-12 credits each semester. Courses could include advanced computer architecture, object oriented design, and network centric systems. You may also have a chance to research and produce a thesis before graduating.

Total costs vary widely between programs, but it's a good idea to plan on spending more than $35,000 on your degree. The good news is that you may find scholarships and discounts to help you meet those costs. Upon graduation, you can pursue a career in computer chip design, aerospace engineering, biomedical engineering, or [machine learning and AI](https://www.computerscience.org/resources/learn-ai/).

### Admission Requirements

Admission to a computer engineering master's degree generally requires the following:

*   [**Bachelor's Degree**](https://www.computerscience.org/degrees/bachelors/computer-engineering/)**:**You need a four-year undergraduate degree from an accredited institution. Schools often expect a technology or engineering-related major.
*   **Minimum GPA:**Many graduate programs require a 3.0 or better for admission.
*   **GRE Scores:**Post-COVID, many master's programs have waived the GRE requirement, but others still expect you to submit scores.
*   **Prerequisites:**You should have taken adequate preparatory coursework in computer science and electrical engineering. Some schools may offer bridge courses if you need them.

### Degree and Specialization Options

A school might offer a master of science in computer engineering, a master of engineering in computer engineering, or even both. These two degrees, while related, are not the same. The master of science emphasizes research and theory, while the master of engineering leans toward real-world application and practice.

A computer engineering master's degree may include specific concentrations such as computer security, AI/ML systems, intelligent physical systems, or devices and nanofab. You can choose a concentration based on your career goals and academic interests.

[](https://www.computerscience.org/degrees/masters/computer-engineering)
### Popular Computer Engineering Courses

As you explore computer engineering master's degrees, you may find a variety of courses offered in different programs. While each school's curriculum is unique, computer engineering generally includes courses like the ones below:

*   **Digital Signal Processing**: This course builds on a background in linear systems analysis. Students explore fast algorithms, quantization effects, discrete-time signals and systems, and digital filter design and implementation.
*   **Embedded Systems and Machine Learning**: Students discover how to apply machine learning to embedded applications. Topics in this course include edge computing, the Internet of Things, model compression, latency, data reuse, and hardware codesign for machine learning.
*   **Biometrics**: Learners explore why computers and networks need security measures to safeguard sensitive data. The course covers the theory, tools, and techniques of biometric security design.
*   **Introduction to System-on-Chip Design**: Topics in this course include cell-based system-on-chip design, pipelining, top-down design flow, and software-hardware co-design and co-simulation.

[](https://www.computerscience.org/degrees/masters/computer-engineering)
### How Much Will Graduate School Cost?

The average computer science master's degree costs $18,274 per year, [according to the National Council for Education Statistics](https://nces.ed.gov/datalab/powerstats/158-national-postsecondary-student-aid-study-2020-graduate-students/averages-medians-percents) (NCES). However, that average stands in the center of a wide range of potential costs. Some schools charge less than $200 per credit, but others go up to almost $2,000.

Factors such as a school's prestige and whether it receives public support can affect the price. Online students may also pay technology fees or other add-on costs.

You do not necessarily have to pay all your expenses out of pocket. Approximately 61% of surveyed online learners [receive financial aid](https://www.computerscience.org/scholarships/) such as scholarships, discounts, or employer support.

*   **[Learn more about how to pay for a degree](https://www.computerscience.org/resources/how-to-pay-for-a-degree/)**
*   **[Explore your scholarship and financial aid options](https://www.computerscience.org/scholarships/)**
*   **[Find companies that may pay for your degree](https://www.computerscience.org/resources/companies-that-pay-for-college/)**
*   **[Discover scholarship programs for women in tech](https://www.computerscience.org/scholarships-women/)**

[](https://www.computerscience.org/degrees/masters/computer-engineering)
Jobs for Master's in Computer Engineering Graduates
---------------------------------------------------

Earning a computer engineering master's degree can position you for engaging, high-paying positions in technology. Consider the following careers:

### [Hardware Engineer](https://www.computerscience.org/careers/computer-hardware-engineer/)

Hardware engineers build routers, networks, processors, circuit boards, and memory devices for computer systems. Often working in research, development, and design companies, these professionals may develop entirely new systems or devise processors for devices containing internet-ready systems, like cars, appliances, or medical equipment. Hardware engineers need a strong background in computer science and electrical engineering.

*   **Required Education:**Bachelor's degree or higher
*   **Median Annual Salary:**[$132,360](https://www.bls.gov/ooh/architecture-and-engineering/computer-hardware-engineers.htm)
*   **Job Outlook (2022-32):**[+5%](https://www.bls.gov/ooh/architecture-and-engineering/computer-hardware-engineers.htm)

### [Software Developer](https://www.computerscience.org/careers/software-developer/)

Software developers envision, design, and create computer programs and applications. Usually working under the direction of a software engineer, these professionals may create user-specific operating systems, such as games or commercial software. Software developers typically need a bachelor's degree, but many employers may require a master's degree. Strong coding skills are a must-have for this profession.

*   **Required Education:**Bachelor's degree or higher
*   **Median/Average Annual Salary:**[$127,260](https://www.bls.gov/ooh/computer-and-information-technology/software-developers.htm#tab-5)
*   **Job Outlook (2022-32):**[+26%](https://www.bls.gov/ooh/computer-and-information-technology/software-developers.htm#tab-6)

### [Computer Programmer](https://www.computerscience.org/careers/computer-programmer/)

Computer programmers write, edit, and test the codes that run computer applications and software. These professionals often have expertise in multiple coding languages. AI's automation of routine work is shrinking the need for computer programmers. Nevertheless, AI cannot do the strategic planning, analysis, or project development that the field requires.

*   **Required Education:**Bachelor's degree or higher
*   **Median Annual Salary:**[$97,800](https://www.bls.gov/ooh/computer-and-information-technology/computer-programmers.htm)
*   **Job Outlook (2022-32):**[-11%](https://www.bls.gov/ooh/computer-and-information-technology/computer-programmers.htm)

### [Computer Network Architects](https://www.computerscience.org/careers/information-technology-architect/)

Sometimes called network engineers, computer network architects design and manage computer networks, including local area networks, wide area networks, and intranets. These professionals often have experience as systems administrators, database administrators, or computer systems analysts. Network architects may need industry certifications in addition to experience and a relevant degree.

*   **Required Education:**Bachelor's degree or higher
*   **Median/Average Annual Salary:**[$126,900](https://www.bls.gov/ooh/computer-and-information-technology/computer-network-architects.htm)
*   **Job Outlook (2022-32):**[+4%](https://www.bls.gov/ooh/computer-and-information-technology/computer-network-architects.htm)

### [Computer Information Researcher](https://www.computerscience.org/careers/computer-information-researcher/)

Working in government agencies, universities, and computer design firms, researchers create new computer systems or improve existing ones. They can specialize in areas such as robotics or programming. These innovative specialists may solve problems in medicine, business, or science. Some researchers also serve as postsecondary professors.

*   **Required Education:**Master's degree or higher
*   **Median Annual Salary:**[$136,620](https://www.bls.gov/ooh/computer-and-information-technology/computer-and-information-research-scientists.htm)
*   **Job Outlook (2022-32):**[+23%](https://www.bls.gov/ooh/computer-and-information-technology/computer-and-information-research-scientists.htm)

[](https://www.computerscience.org/degrees/masters/computer-engineering)
Choosing the Right Computer Engineering Graduate Program
--------------------------------------------------------

To maximize your learning experience, choose an accredited computer engineering program that is affordable, convenient, customizable, and local.

*   **Accredited:**An institutionally accredited school gives you access to financial aid and career opportunities that non-accredited institutions cannot match. Program accreditation does not apply to graduate-level CS degrees.
*   **Affordable:**Look beyond the price tag. Does your potential school offer scholarships, locked-in tuition, free textbooks, discounts, or other incentives?
*   **Convenient:**Many students find asynchronous courses and shorter terms help them finish their requirements on time while maintaining work, family, or community obligations.
*   **Customizable:**Can you choose a concentration relevant to your career goals? Does your program incorporate professional certifications, micro-credentials, digital badges, or trade skills certificates?
*   **Local:** Online education lets you choose from schools worldwide, but learning locally may be your best option. If you live near campus, you can participate in on-site laboratories, special events, and job fairs specific to computer engineering.

### Should You Get Your Master's Degree Online?

In the fall of 2021, the [NCES reported](https://nces.ed.gov/fastfacts/display.asp?id=80) that 56% of graduate learners were studying online, and 40% were earning their entire degrees by distance education. The field is burgeoning, but is online education effective? Research says yes — with some qualifications.

[Wiley's 2023 study of online learners](https://universityservices.wiley.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/06/202306-VOL2023-report-WUNI-final.pdf) found that 91% of online students viewed their educational experience positively, and 92% of graduates said they had achieved a positive outcome because of their degree. Still, 18% of learners planned to switch to a campus-based program, primarily because they missed the peer-to-peer interaction.

### Discover more paths to learning computer science:

[](https://www.computerscience.org/degrees/masters/computer-engineering)
More Questions About Master's in Computer Engineering Programs
--------------------------------------------------------------

### What can you do with a master's in computer engineering?

With a master's in computer engineering, you can pursue a career as a hardware engineer, network architect, cybersecurity analyst, or information systems manager. This degree can also position you for a Ph.D. and a subsequent career in teaching or research.

### Is a master's in computer engineering the same as a computer science master's?

Computer engineering and computer science are related but different subjects. Computer engineering focuses on building hardware systems, while computer science is a holistic field concerned with theory and analysis.

### How long does it take to finish a computer engineering master's?

Most computer engineering master's programs take two years to finish. However, not all students work on the same timeline. Part-time learners may need more time, but accelerated BA/MS students might earn both degrees in five years.

### Is going to graduate school for computer engineering worth it?

In November 2023, [Payscale reported](https://www.payscale.com/research/US/Degree=Master_of_Science_(MS)%2C_Computer_Engineering_(CE)/Salary) that people with a master's in computer engineering earned an average annual salary of $108,000. People with a BS in computer engineering earned an average of $96,000.

[According to the NCES](https://nces.ed.gov/datalab/powerstats/158-national-postsecondary-student-aid-study-2020-graduate-students/averages-medians-percents), the average CS master's degree costs $18,274 annually. Assuming a total cost of $37,000 for a two-year degree and average salaries before and after earning your master's, you could realize a positive ROI in 25 months.

**Dayton** () is a city in [Montgomery County, Ohio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Montgomery_County,_Ohio "Montgomery County, Ohio"), United States, and its [county seat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/County_seat "County seat").[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-GR6-5)[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-Dayton_annexed_land_to_stop_merger-6) It is the [sixth-most populous city](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_cities_in_Ohio "List of cities in Ohio") in Ohio with a population of 137,644 at the [2020 census](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2020_United_States_census "2020 United States census"), while the [Dayton metropolitan area](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_metropolitan_area "Dayton metropolitan area") has an estimated 822,000 residents and is the state's fourth-largest metropolitan area.[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-PopEstCBSA-7) Dayton is located within Ohio's [Miami Valley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miami_Valley "Miami Valley") region, 50 miles (80 km) north of [Cincinnati](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cincinnati "Cincinnati") and 60 miles (97 km) west-southwest of [Columbus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Columbus,_Ohio "Columbus, Ohio").

Dayton was founded in 1796 along the [Great Miami River](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Miami_River "Great Miami River") and named after [Jonathan Dayton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jonathan_Dayton "Jonathan Dayton"), a [Founding Father](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Founding_Fathers_of_the_United_States "Founding Fathers of the United States") who owned a significant amount of land in the area.[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-Brief_History_of_Dayton-8) It grew in the 19th century as a [canal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Canal "Canal") town and was home to many [patents](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Patent "Patent") and [inventors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inventor "Inventor"), most notably the [Wright brothers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wright_brothers "Wright brothers"), who developed the first successful motor-operated [airplane](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Airplane "Airplane").[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-Dayton_Inventions-9)[[10]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-Dayton_Aviation_History-10) It later developed an industrialized economy and was home to the [Dayton Project](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Project "Dayton Project"), a branch of the larger [Manhattan Project](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manhattan_Project "Manhattan Project"), to develop [polonium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polonium "Polonium") triggers used in early atomic bombs. With the decline of heavy manufacturing in the late 20th century, Dayton's businesses have diversified into a [service economy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Service_economy "Service economy").

Ohio's borders are within 500 miles (800 km) of roughly 60 percent of the country's population and manufacturing infrastructure, making Dayton a [logistics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logistics "Logistics") hub.[[11]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-11)[[12]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-PolitiFact-12) The city is home to [Wright-Patterson Air Force Base](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wright-Patterson_Air_Force_Base "Wright-Patterson Air Force Base"), a significant contributor to [research and development](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Research_and_development "Research and development") in the industrial, [aeronautical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aeronautics "Aeronautics"), and [astronautical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Astronautics "Astronautics") engineering fields. Along with defense and aerospace, [healthcare](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Healthcare "Healthcare") accounts for much of the Dayton area's economy.[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-Dayton_area_hospitals-13)[[14]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-Economic_Impact-14) Significant institutions in Dayton include the [Air Force Institute of Technology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_Force_Institute_of_Technology "Air Force Institute of Technology"), [Carillon Historical Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carillon_Historical_Park "Carillon Historical Park"), [Dayton Art Institute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Art_Institute "Dayton Art Institute"), [Dayton Performing Arts Alliance](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Performing_Arts_Alliance "Dayton Performing Arts Alliance"), [National Museum of the United States Air Force](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Museum_of_the_United_States_Air_Force "National Museum of the United States Air Force"), and [University of Dayton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Dayton "University of Dayton").

Dayton was founded on April 1, 1796, by 12 settlers known as the Thompson Party. They traveled in March from [Cincinnati](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cincinnati "Cincinnati") up the [Great Miami River](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Miami_River "Great Miami River") by [pirogue](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pirogue "Pirogue") and landed at what is now St. Clair Street, where they found two small camps of [Native Americans](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indigenous_peoples_of_the_Americas "Indigenous peoples of the Americas"). Among the Thompson Party was Benjamin Van Cleve,[[15]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-15) whose memoirs provide insights into the Ohio Valley's history. Two other groups traveling overland arrived several days later.[[16]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-16) The oldest surviving building is [Newcom Tavern](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Newcom_Tavern "Newcom Tavern"), which was used for various purposes, including housing [Dayton's first church](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Westminster_Presbyterian_Church_(Dayton) "Westminster Presbyterian Church (Dayton)"), which is still in existence.[[17]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-17)

In 1797, [Daniel C. Cooper](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Daniel_C._Cooper "Daniel C. Cooper") laid out [Mad River Road](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mad_River_Road "Mad River Road"), the first overland connection between Cincinnati and Dayton, opening the "Mad River Country" to settlement. Ohio was admitted into the [Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Union_(American_Civil_War) "Union (American Civil War)") in 1803, and the village of Dayton was incorporated in 1805 and chartered as a city in 1841. The city was named after [Jonathan Dayton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jonathan_Dayton "Jonathan Dayton"), a captain in the [American Revolutionary War](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War "American Revolutionary War") who signed the [U.S. Constitution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Constitution "United States Constitution") and owned a significant amount of land in the area.[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-Brief_History_of_Dayton-8) In 1827, construction on the Dayton–Cincinnati canal began, which provided a better way to transport goods from Dayton to Cincinnati and contributed significantly to Dayton's economic growth during the 1800s.[[8]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-Brief_History_of_Dayton-8)

[![Image 16](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Dayton%2C_Ohio_1870._LOC_73694508.jpg/250px-Dayton%2C_Ohio_1870._LOC_73694508.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Dayton,_Ohio_1870._LOC_73694508.jpg)

Dayton in 1870

Innovation led to business growth in the region. In 1884, [John Henry Patterson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Henry_Patterson_(NCR_owner) "John Henry Patterson (NCR owner)") acquired James Ritty's National Manufacturing Company along with his [cash register](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cash_register "Cash register") patents and formed the [National Cash Register Company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NCR_Corporation "NCR Corporation") (NCR). The company manufactured the first mechanical cash registers and played a crucial role in the shaping of Dayton's reputation as an epicenter for manufacturing in the early 1900s. In 1906, [Charles F. Kettering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_F._Kettering "Charles F. Kettering"), a leading engineer at the company, helped develop the first electric cash register, which propelled NCR into the national spotlight.[[18]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-18) NCR also helped develop the [US Navy Bombe](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/US_Navy_Bombe "US Navy Bombe"), a code-breaking machine that helped crack the [Enigma machine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enigma_machine "Enigma machine") cipher during [World War II](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_War_II "World War II").[[19]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-19)

Dayton has been the home for many patents and inventions since the 1870s.[[9]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-Dayton_Inventions-9)[[20]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-20) According to the [National Park Service](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Park_Service "National Park Service"), citing information from the [U.S. Patent Office](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._Patent_Office "U.S. Patent Office"), Dayton had granted more patents per capita than any other U.S. city in 1890 and ranked fifth in the nation as early as 1870.[[21]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-21) The [Wright brothers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wright_brothers "Wright brothers"), inventors of the airplane, and [Charles F. Kettering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_F._Kettering "Charles F. Kettering"), world-renowned for his numerous inventions, hailed from Dayton.[[22]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-22) The city was also home to [James Ritty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Ritty "James Ritty")'s Incorruptible Cashier, the first mechanical cash register, and [Arthur E. Morgan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arthur_Ernest_Morgan "Arthur Ernest Morgan")'s hydraulic jump, a flood prevention mechanism that helped pioneer [hydraulic engineering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydraulic_engineering "Hydraulic engineering").[[23]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-River_Walk-23)[[24]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-Morgan-24)[Paul Laurence Dunbar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Laurence_Dunbar "Paul Laurence Dunbar"), an African-American poet and novelist, penned his most famous works in the late 19th century and became an integral part of the city's history.[[25]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-25)

### Birthplace of aviation

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Dayton,_Ohio&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section: Birthplace of aviation")]

Powered aviation began in Dayton. [Orville and Wilbur Wright](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wright_brothers "Wright brothers") were the first to construct and demonstrate powered flight. Although the first flight was in [Kitty Hawk, North Carolina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kitty_Hawk,_North_Carolina "Kitty Hawk, North Carolina"), their Wright Flyer was built in and returned to Dayton for improvements and further flights at [Huffman Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Huffman_Field "Huffman Field"), a cow pasture eight miles (13 km) northeast of Dayton, near the current Wright-Patterson Air Force Base.

When the government tried to move development to [Langley Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Langley_Air_Force_Base "Langley Air Force Base") in southern Virginia, six Dayton businessmen including Edward A. Deeds, formed the Dayton-Wright Airplane Company in Moraine and established a flying field. Deeds also opened a field to the north in the flood plain of the Great Miami River between the confluences of that river, the Stillwater River, and the Mad River (near downtown Dayton). Later named [McCook Field](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/McCook_Field "McCook Field") for Alexander McDowell McCook, an American Civil War general, this became the Army Signal Corps' primary aviation research and training location. Wilbur Wright also purchased land near Huffman prairie to continue their research.

During World War I, the Army purchased 40 acres adjacent to Huffman Prairie for the Fairfield Aviation General Supply Depot. As airplanes developed more capability, they needed more runway space than McCook could offer, and a new location was sought. The Patterson family formed the Dayton Air Service Committee, Inc which held a campaign that raised $425,000 in two days and purchased 4,520.47 acres (18.2937 km 2) northeast of Dayton, including Wilbur Wright Field and the Huffman Prairie Flying Field. Wright Field was "formally dedicated" on October 12, 1927. After World War II, Wright Field and the adjacent Patterson Field, Dayton Army Air Field, and Clinton Army Air Field were merged as the Headquarters, Air Force Technical Base. On January 13, 1948, the facility was renamed [Wright-Patterson Air Force Base](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wright-Patterson_Air_Force_Base "Wright-Patterson Air Force Base").

[![Image 17](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/ff/Ludlow_Street_-_North_-_Dayton_Ohio_great_flood_of_1913.jpg/250px-Ludlow_Street_-_North_-_Dayton_Ohio_great_flood_of_1913.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Ludlow_Street_-_North_-_Dayton_Ohio_great_flood_of_1913.jpg)

Flooding on Ludlow Street in downtown Dayton during the [Great Dayton Flood](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Dayton_Flood "Great Dayton Flood"), 1913

A catastrophic flood in March 1913, known as the [Great Dayton Flood](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Dayton_Flood "Great Dayton Flood"), led to the creation of the [Miami Conservancy District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miami_Conservancy_District "Miami Conservancy District"), a series of dams as well as hydraulic pumps installed around Dayton, in 1914.[[26]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-26)

### Contribution in World War Two

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Dayton,_Ohio&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Contribution in World War Two")]

Like other cities across the country, Dayton was heavily involved in the war effort during World War II. Several locations around the city hosted the [Dayton Project](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Project "Dayton Project"), a branch of the larger [Manhattan Project](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Manhattan_Project "Manhattan Project"), to develop [polonium](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polonium "Polonium") triggers used in early atomic bombs.[[27]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-27) The war efforts led to a manufacturing boom throughout the city, including high-demand for housing and other services. At one point, emergency housing was put into place due to a housing shortage in the region, much of which is still in use today.[[28]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-28)

[Alan Turing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alan_Turing "Alan Turing") is widely considered to be the father of theoretical computer science and artificial intelligence. He visited the [National Cash Register](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Cash_Register "National Cash Register") (NCR) company in Dayton in December 1942. He was able to show that it was not necessary to build 336 [Bombes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bombes "Bombes"), so the initial order was scaled down to 96 machines to decipher German Enigma-machine-encrypted secret messages during World War II.[[29]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-29)

Between the 1940s and the 1970s, the city saw significant growth in suburban areas from population migration. Veterans were returning from military service in large numbers seeking industrial and manufacturing jobs, a part of the local industry that was expanding rapidly. Advancements in architecture also contributed to the suburban boom. New, modernized shopping centers and the [Interstate Highway System](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interstate_Highway_System "Interstate Highway System") allowed workers to commute greater distances and families to live further from the downtown area. More than 127,000 homes were built in Montgomery County during the 1950s.[[30]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-30)

During this time, the city was the site of several race riots, including one in 1955 following the murder of [Emmett Till](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emmett_Till "Emmett Till"), the [1966 Dayton race riot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1966_Dayton_race_riot "1966 Dayton race riot"), two in 1967 (following a speech by civil rights activist [H. Rap Brown](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H._Rap_Brown "H. Rap Brown") and another following the [police killing](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Police_killing "Police killing") of an African American man), and one in 1968 as part of the nationwide [King assassination riots](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/King_assassination_riots "King assassination riots").[[31]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-31)

Since the 1980s, however, Dayton's population has declined, mainly due to the loss of manufacturing jobs and decentralization of metropolitan areas, as well as the national [housing crisis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_housing_bubble "United States housing bubble") that began in 2008.[[32]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-Dayton's_decline_%E2%80%93_Hampton_Inst-32) While much of the state has suffered for similar reasons, the impact on Dayton has been greater than most. By 2013, Dayton had the third-greatest percentage loss of population in the state since the 1980s, behind Cleveland and Youngstown.[[32]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-Dayton's_decline_%E2%80%93_Hampton_Inst-32) Despite this, Dayton has begun diversifying its workforce from manufacturing into other growing sectors such as healthcare and education.[[33]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-Dayton_decline_%E2%80%93_NBCNews-33)

In 1995, the [Dayton Agreement](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Agreement "Dayton Agreement"), a peace accord between the parties to the hostilities of the [conflict in Bosnia-Herzegovina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bosnian_War "Bosnian War") and [the former Yugoslavia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yugoslav_Wars "Yugoslav Wars"), was negotiated at [Wright-Patterson Air Force Base](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wright-Patterson_Air_Force_Base "Wright-Patterson Air Force Base"), near Fairborn, Ohio, from November 1 to 21. The agreement formally ended the conflict in the [Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republic_of_Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina") on December 14, 1995.

[Richard Holbrooke](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Holbrooke "Richard Holbrooke") wrote about these events in his memoirs:

> There was also a real Dayton out there, a charming Ohio city, famous as the birthplace of the [Wright brothers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wright_brothers "Wright brothers"). Its citizens energized us from the outset. Unlike the population of, say, New York City, [Geneva](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Geneva "Geneva") or [Washington](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington,_D.C. "Washington, D.C."), which would scarcely notice another conference, Daytonians were proud to be part of history. Large signs at the commercial airport hailed Dayton as the "temporary center of international peace." The local newspapers and television stations covered the story from every angle, drawing the people deeper into the proceedings. When we ventured into a restaurant or a shopping center downtown, people crowded around, saying that they were praying for us. [Warren Christopher](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warren_Christopher "Warren Christopher") was given at least one standing ovation in a restaurant. Families on the airbase placed "candles of peace" in their front windows, and people gathered in peace vigils outside the base. One day they formed a "peace chain," although it was not large enough to surround the sprawling eight-thousand-acre base. Ohio's famous ethnic diversity was on display.[[34]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-34)

Downtown expansion that began in the 2000s has helped revitalize the city and encourage growth. [Day Air Ballpark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Day_Air_Ballpark "Day Air Ballpark"), home of the [Dayton Dragons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Dragons "Dayton Dragons"), was built in 2000. The highly successful minor league baseball team has been an integral part of Dayton's culture.[[35]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-DragonsSellout-35) In 2001, the city's public park system, [Five Rivers MetroParks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Five_Rivers_MetroParks "Five Rivers MetroParks"), built RiverScape MetroPark, an outdoor entertainment venue that attracts more than 400,000 visitors each year.[[36]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-36) A new performance arts theater, the [Schuster Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Schuster_Center "Schuster Center"), opened in 2003.[[37]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-37) A large health network in the region, [Premier Health Partners](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Premier_Health_Partners "Premier Health Partners"), expanded its [Miami Valley Hospital](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miami_Valley_Hospital "Miami Valley Hospital") with a 12-story tower addition.[[38]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-38)

In 2010, the Downtown Dayton Partnership, in cooperation with the City of Dayton and community leaders, introduced the Greater Downtown Dayton Plan. It focuses on job creation and retention, infrastructure improvements, housing, recreation, and collaboration. The plan is to be implemented through the year 2020.[[39]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-39)

[![Image 18](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Geography_of_Ohio_-_DPLA_-_aaba7b3295ff6973b6fd1e23e33cde14_%28page_123%29_%28cropped%29.jpg/250px-Geography_of_Ohio_-_DPLA_-_aaba7b3295ff6973b6fd1e23e33cde14_%28page_123%29_%28cropped%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Geography_of_Ohio_-_DPLA_-_aaba7b3295ff6973b6fd1e23e33cde14_(page_123)_(cropped).jpg)

A photograph of the Miami and Erie Canal from _Geography of Ohio_, 1923

Dayton is known as the "Gem City". The nickname's origin is uncertain, but several theories exist. In the early 19th century, a well-known [racehorse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Racehorse "Racehorse") named Gem hailed from Dayton. In 1845, an article published in the _Cincinnati Daily Chronicle_ by an author known as T stated:

> In a small bend of the Great Miami River, with canals on the east and south, it can be fairly said, without infringing on the rights of others, that Dayton is the gem of all our interior towns. It possesses wealth, refinement, enterprise, and a beautiful country, beautifully developed.[[40]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-Dayton_FAQs-40)

In the late 1840s, Major William D. Bickham of the _Dayton Journal_ began a campaign to nickname Dayton the "Gem City." The name was adopted by the city's Board of Trade several years later.[[40]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-Dayton_FAQs-40)[Paul Laurence Dunbar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Laurence_Dunbar "Paul Laurence Dunbar") referred to the nickname in his poem, "Toast to Dayton", as noted in the following excerpt:

> She shall ever claim our duty,
> 
>  For she shines—the brightest gem
> 
>  That has ever decked with beauty
> 
> Dear Ohio's diadem.[[41]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-41)

Dayton also plays a role in a nickname given to the state of Ohio, "Birthplace of Aviation." Dayton is the hometown of the [Wright brothers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wright_brothers "Wright brothers"), aviation pioneers who are credited with inventing and building the first practical airplane in history. After their first manned flights in [Kitty Hawk, North Carolina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kitty_Hawk,_North_Carolina "Kitty Hawk, North Carolina"), which they had chosen due to its ideal weather and climate conditions, the Wrights returned to Dayton and continued testing at nearby [Huffman Prairie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Huffman_Prairie "Huffman Prairie").[[42]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-42)

Additionally, Dayton is colloquially referred to as "Little Detroit".[[43]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-DDN_Hannon-43) This nickname comes from Dayton's prominence as a Midwestern manufacturing center.[[44]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-44)

[![Image 19](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/db/Downtown_Dayton%2C_Ohio.jpg/250px-Downtown_Dayton%2C_Ohio.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Downtown_Dayton,_Ohio.jpg)

Aerial view of Downtown Dayton (NE to SW)

According to the [United States Census Bureau](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Census_Bureau "United States Census Bureau"), the city has a total area of 56.50 square miles (146.33 km 2), of which 55.65 square miles (144.13 km 2) is land and 0.85 square miles (2.20 km 2) is water.[[45]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-Gazetteer_files-45)

Dayton's climate features warm, muggy summers and cold, dry winters, and is classified as a [humid continental climate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Humid_continental_climate "Humid continental climate") ([Köppen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen climate classification")_Dfa_). Unless otherwise noted, all normal figures quoted within the text below are from the official climatology station, Dayton International Airport, at an elevation of 1,000 ft (304.8 m) about 10 mi (16 km) to the north of downtown Dayton, which lies within the valley of the [Miami River](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Miami_River "Great Miami River"); thus temperatures there are typically cooler than in downtown.[[46]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-46)

At the airport, monthly mean temperatures range from 27.5°F (−2.5°C) in January to 74.1°F (23.4°C) in July. The highest temperature ever recorded in Dayton was 108°F (42°C) on July 22, 1901, and the coldest was −28°F (−33°C) on February 13 during the [Great Blizzard of 1899](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Blizzard_of_1899 "Great Blizzard of 1899"). On average, there are 14 days of 90°F (32°C)+ highs and 4.5 nights of sub-0°F (−18°C) lows annually. Snow is moderate, with a normal seasonal accumulation of 23.3 in (59 cm),[[a]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-48) usually occurring from November to March, occasionally April, and rarely October. Precipitation averages 41.1 inches (1,040 mm) annually, with total rainfall peaking in May.

Dayton is subject to severe weather typical of the [Midwestern United States](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Midwestern_United_States "Midwestern United States"). [Tornadoes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tornado "Tornado") are possible from the spring to the fall. Floods, blizzards, and severe thunderstorms can also occur.

On Memorial Day of 2019, Dayton suffered extensive property damage and one death during a [tornado outbreak](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tornado_outbreak_sequence_of_May_2019 "Tornado outbreak sequence of May 2019"), in which a total of 15 tornadoes touched down in the Dayton area.[[48]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-2019Tornado-WDTN-49) Although some of the tornadoes were only [EF0](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enhanced_Fujita_scale "Enhanced Fujita scale") and remained on the ground for less than a mile, [one](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Dayton_tornado "2019 Dayton tornado") was an EF4 measuring a half-mile-wide (805 meters), which tore through the communities of Brookville, Trotwood, Dayton, Northridge, and Riverside.[[49]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-50)[[50]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-51) Several streets were closed, including portions of I-75 and North Dixie Drive in Northridge. 64,000 residents lost power and much of the region's water supply was cut off.[[51]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-52)[[48]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-2019Tornado-WDTN-49)

The Dayton Audubon Society is the [National Audubon Society](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Audubon_Society "National Audubon Society")'s local chapter. The Dayton chapter manages local activities contributing to the annual, hemisphere-wide [Christmas Bird Count](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christmas_Bird_Count "Christmas Bird Count").[[55]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-60) The Chapter began participation in the National Count in 1924. The local Count was initially coordinated by Ben Blincoe, who was succeeded by Jim Hill in 1970. In the mid-1960s, the freezing of Lake Erie and associated marshlands led species of waterfowl to appear in the Dayton-area, where surface waters remained unfrozen. Nine varieties of birds have been observed every year in the Dayton area: [downy woodpecker](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Downy_woodpecker "Downy woodpecker"), [Carolina chickadee](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carolina_chickadee "Carolina chickadee"), [tufted titmouse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tufted_titmouse "Tufted titmouse"), [brown creeper](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brown_creeper "Brown creeper"), [northern cardinal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Northern_cardinal "Northern cardinal"), [dark-eyed junco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dark-eyed_junco "Dark-eyed junco"), [American tree sparrow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_tree_sparrow "American tree sparrow"), [song sparrow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Song_sparrow "Song sparrow") and [American crow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_crow "American crow").[[56]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-61)[[57]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-62)

[![Image 20](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/DaytonView.jpg/960px-DaytonView.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:DaytonView.jpg)

Panorama of Dayton

Unlike many Midwestern cities its age, Dayton has very broad and straight downtown streets (generally two or three full lanes in each direction) that improved access to the downtown even after the automobile became popular. The main reason for the broad streets was that Dayton was a marketing and shipping center from its beginning; streets were broad to enable wagons drawn by teams of three to four pairs of oxen to turn around. Also, some of today's streets were once barge canals flanked by draw-paths.

[![Image 21](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/de/Old_Montgomery_County_Courthouse_-_Dayton%2C_Ohio_%282021%29.jpg/250px-Old_Montgomery_County_Courthouse_-_Dayton%2C_Ohio_%282021%29.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Old_Montgomery_County_Courthouse_-_Dayton,_Ohio_(2021).jpg)

The [Old Montgomery County Courthouse](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Montgomery_County_Courthouse_(Ohio) "Montgomery County Courthouse (Ohio)"), built in 1847, and the current courthouse behind it.

A courthouse building was built in downtown Dayton in 1888 to supplement Dayton's original [Neoclassical](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neoclassical_architecture "Neoclassical architecture") courthouse, which still stands. This second, "new" courthouse has since been replaced with new facilities as well as a park. The Old Court House has been a favored political campaign stop. On September 17, 1859, [Abraham Lincoln](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln "Abraham Lincoln") delivered an address on its steps. Eight other presidents have visited the courthouse, either as presidents or during presidential campaigns: [Andrew Johnson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrew_Johnson "Andrew Johnson"), [James Garfield](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Garfield "James Garfield"), [John F. Kennedy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy "John F. Kennedy"), [Lyndon B. Johnson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyndon_B._Johnson "Lyndon B. Johnson"), [Richard Nixon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Nixon "Richard Nixon"), [Gerald Ford](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerald_Ford "Gerald Ford"), [Ronald Reagan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ronald_Reagan "Ronald Reagan"), and [Bill Clinton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bill_Clinton "Bill Clinton").[[58]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-63)

The [Dayton Arcade](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Arcade "Dayton Arcade"), which opened on March 3, 1904, was built in the hopes of replacing open-air markets throughout the city. Throughout the decades, the Arcade has gone through many transformations but has retained its charm. Some of its main features include a Flemish facade at the Third Street entrance, a glass dome above the Arcade rotunda, and a chateau roof line above the Third Street facade.[[59]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-64) The Dayton Arcade is currently under renovations with no official completion date set.

In 2009, the [CareSource](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CareSource "CareSource") Management Group finished construction of a $55 million corporate headquarters in downtown Dayton. The 300,000-square-foot (28,000 m 2), 10-story building was downtown's first new office tower in more than a decade.[[60]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-65)

Dayton's two tallest buildings are the [Kettering Tower](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kettering_Tower "Kettering Tower") at 408 ft (124 m) and the [KeyBank Tower](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KeyBank_Tower "KeyBank Tower") at 385 ft (117 m).[[61]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-66) Kettering Tower was originally Winters Tower, the headquarters of Winters Bank. The building was renamed after [Virginia Kettering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Virginia_Kettering "Virginia Kettering") when Winters was merged into [Bank One](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_One "Bank One"). KeyBank Tower was known as the [MeadWestvaco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MeadWestvaco "MeadWestvaco") Tower before [KeyBank](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/KeyBank "KeyBank") gained naming rights to the building in 2008.[[62]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-67)

[Ted Rall](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ted_Rall "Ted Rall") said in 2015 that over the last five decades Dayton has been demolishing some of its architecturally significant buildings to reduce the city's [rental vacancy rate](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rental_vacancy_rate "Rental vacancy rate") and thus increase the occupancy rate.[[63]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-68)

[![Image 22](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Central_Avenue_Historic_District_in_Dayton.jpg/250px-Central_Avenue_Historic_District_in_Dayton.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Central_Avenue_Historic_District_in_Dayton.jpg)

The [Central Avenue Historic District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_Avenue_Historic_District_(Dayton,_Ohio) "Central Avenue Historic District (Dayton, Ohio)") in [Grafton Hill](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grafton_Hill,_Dayton,_Ohio "Grafton Hill, Dayton, Ohio")

Dunbar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wright-Dunbar,_Dayton,_Ohio "Wright-Dunbar, Dayton, Ohio"), [Dayton View](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_View,_Dayton,_Ohio "Dayton View, Dayton, Ohio"), [Grafton Hill](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grafton_Hill,_Dayton,_Ohio "Grafton Hill, Dayton, Ohio"), [McPherson Town](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/McPherson_Town,_Dayton,_Ohio "McPherson Town, Dayton, Ohio"), [Webster Station](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Webster_Station,_Dayton,_Ohio "Webster Station, Dayton, Ohio"), [Huffman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Huffman,_Dayton,_Ohio "Huffman, Dayton, Ohio"), [Kenilworth](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenilworth_District,_Dayton,_Ohio "Kenilworth District, Dayton, Ohio"), [St. Anne's Dayton's suburbs with a population of 10,000 or more include [Beavercreek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beavercreek,_Ohio "Beavercreek, Ohio"), [Centerville](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Centerville,_Ohio "Centerville, Ohio"), [Clayton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clayton,_Ohio "Clayton, Ohio"), [Englewood](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Englewood,_Ohio "Englewood, Ohio"), [Fairborn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fairborn,_Ohio "Fairborn, Ohio"), [Harrison Township](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harrison_Township,_Montgomery_County,_Ohio "Harrison Township, Montgomery County, Ohio"), [Huber Heights](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Huber_Heights,_Ohio "Huber Heights, Ohio"), [Kettering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kettering,_Ohio "Kettering, Ohio"), [Miami Township](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miami_Township,_Montgomery_County,_Ohio "Miami Township, Montgomery County, Ohio"), [Miamisburg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miamisburg,_Ohio "Miamisburg, Ohio"), [Oakwood](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oakwood,_Montgomery_County,_Ohio "Oakwood, Montgomery County, Ohio"), [Riverside](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Riverside,_Ohio "Riverside, Ohio"), [Springboro](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Springboro,_Ohio "Springboro, Ohio"), [Trotwood](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trotwood,_Ohio "Trotwood, Ohio"), [Vandalia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vandalia,_Ohio "Vandalia, Ohio"), [Washington Township](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Township,_Montgomery_County,_Ohio "Washington Township, Montgomery County, Ohio"), [West Carrollton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/West_Carrollton,_Ohio "West Carrollton, Ohio"), and [Xenia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xenia,_Ohio "Xenia, Ohio").

In the federal government's [National Urban Policy and New Community Development Act of 1970](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Urban_Policy_and_New_Community_Development_Act_of_1970 "National Urban Policy and New Community Development Act of 1970"), funding was provided for thirteen ["new towns"](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_planned_cities "List of planned cities") or planned cities throughout the country. One location was set to become a suburb of Dayton and was known variously as Brookwood or Newfields.[[65]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-hudnews-70) The goal was to have an entirely new suburb that would eventually house about 35,000 residents. The new town was to be located between Trotwood and Brookville, and modeled on the ideas of [Ian McHarg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ian_McHarg "Ian McHarg"). The project was abandoned in 1978 and most of the land became [Sycamore State Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_protected_areas_of_Ohio#State_parks "List of protected areas of Ohio").[[66]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-71)

Dayton's city proper population declined significantly from a peak of 262,332 residents in 1960 to 137,644 residents in 2020. This was in part due to the slowdown of the region's manufacturing sector. The metropolitan area as a whole has experienced both population growth and decreases since 1960, with the overall trend leaning towards growth for the metro area.[[67]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-72) The city's most populous ethnic group, white, declined from 78.1% in 1960 to 51.7% by 2010.[[68]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-73)
