As of the census of 2020, there were 137,644 people living in the city, for a population density of 2,466.47 people per square mile (952.31/km 2). There were 68,899 housing units. The racial makeup of the city (including Hispanics in the racial counts) was 47.6% White, 40.7% Black or African American, 0.4% Native American, 1.4% Asian, 0.1% Pacific Islander, 3.3% from some other race, and 6.6% from two or more races. Separately, 5.7% of the population were Hispanic or Latino of any race.[[72]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-2020_census-77)

There were 63,308 households, out of which 22.1% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 24.5% were [married couples](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marriage "Marriage") living together, 30.9% had a male householder with no spouse present, and 38.2% had a female householder with no spouse present. 47.4% of all households were made up of individuals, and 14.6% were someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 1.95, and the average family size was 2.83.[[72]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-2020_census-77)

18.9% of the city's population were under the age of 18, 65.0% were 18 to 64, and 16.1% were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 38.4. For every 100 females, there were 101.5 males.[[72]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-2020_census-77)

According to the U.S. Census [American Community Survey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Community_Survey "American Community Survey"), for the period 2016-2020 the estimated median annual income for a household in the city was $43,780, and the median income for a family was $60,408. About 25.4% of the population were living below the [poverty line](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Poverty_line "Poverty line"), including 39.5% of those under age 18 and 21.5% of those age 65 or over. About 53.6% of the population were employed, and 24.4% had a bachelor's degree or higher.[[72]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-2020_census-77)

As of the 2010 census,[[73]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-wwwcensusgov-78) there were 141,759 people, 58,404 households, and 31,064 families residing in the city. The population density was 2,543.2 inhabitants per square mile (981.9/km 2). There were 74,065 housing units at an average density of 1,330.9 per square mile (513.9/km 2). The racial makeup of the city was 51.7% White, 42.9% African American, 0.3% Native American, 0.9% Asian, 1.3% from other races, and 2.9% from two or more races. Hispanic or Latino residents of any race were 3.0% of the population.

There were 58,404 households, of which 28.3% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 25.9% were married couples living together, 21.4% had a female householder with no husband present, 5.9% had a male householder with no wife present, and 46.8% were non-families. 38.8% of all households were made up of individuals, and 11.2% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.26, and the average family size was 3.03.

The median age in the city was 34.4 years. 22.9% of residents were under the age of 18; 14.2% were between the ages of 18 and 24; 25.3% were from 25 to 44; 25.8% were from 45 to 64, and 11.8% were 65 years of age or older. The gender makeup of the city was 48.7% male and 51.3% female.

Dayton's crime declined between 2003 and 2008 in key categories according to FBI [Uniform Crime Reports](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uniform_Crime_Reports "Uniform Crime Reports") and Dayton Police Department data.[[74]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-79) In 2009, crime continued to fall in the city of Dayton. Crime in the categories of forcible rape, aggravated assault, property crime, motor vehicle theft, robbery, burglary, theft and arson all showed declines for 2009. Overall, crime in Dayton dropped 40% over the previous year.[[75]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-80) The Dayton Police Department reported a total of 39 murders in 2016, which marked a 39.3% increase in homicides from 2015.[[76]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-81)

[John Dillinger](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Dillinger "John Dillinger"), a [bank robber](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bank_robber "Bank robber") during the early 1930s, was captured and arrested by Dayton city police while visiting his girlfriend at a high-class [boarding house](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boarding_house "Boarding house") in downtown Dayton.[[77]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-82)[[78]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-83)

On August 4, 2019, [a mass shooting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019_Dayton_shooting "2019 Dayton shooting") took place in Dayton. Ten people were killed, including the perpetrator, and twenty-seven were injured.[[79]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-84)

[![Image 23](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/445aw-1.jpg/250px-445aw-1.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:445aw-1.jpg)

[Lockheed C-5 Galaxy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lockheed_C-5_Galaxy "Lockheed C-5 Galaxy") at [Wright-Patterson Air Force Base](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wright-Patterson_Air_Force_Base "Wright-Patterson Air Force Base")

Dayton's economy is relatively diversified and vital to the overall economy of the state of Ohio. In 2008 and 2009, _[Site Selection](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Site\_Selection "Site Selection")_ magazine ranked Dayton the #1 medium-sized metropolitan area in the U.S. for economic development.[[80]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-Site_Selection_ranking-85)[[81]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-siteselection.com-86) Dayton is also among the top 100 metropolitan areas in both exports and export-related jobs, ranked 16 and 14 respectively by the [Brookings Institution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brookings_Institution "Brookings Institution"). The 2010 report placed the value of exports at $4.7 billion and the number of export-related jobs at 44,133.[[82]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-87) The Dayton Metropolitan Statistical Area ranks 4th in Ohio's Gross Domestic Product with a 2008 industry total of $33.78 billion.[[83]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-88) Additionally, Dayton ranks third among 11 major metropolitan areas in Ohio for exports to foreign countries.[[84]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-89) The Dayton Development Coalition is attempting to leverage the region's large water capacity, estimated to be 1.5 trillion gallons of [renewable](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Renewable "Renewable") water aquifers, to attract new businesses.[[85]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-90)[[86]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-91) Moody's Investment Services revised Dayton's bond rating from A1 to the stronger rating of Aa2 as part of its global recalibration process. [Standard & Poor's](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standard_%26_Poor%27s "Standard & Poor's") upgraded Dayton's rating from A+ to AA− in the summer of 2009.[[87]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-92)

_[Bloomberg Businessweek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bloomberg\_Businessweek "Bloomberg Businessweek")_ ranked Dayton in 2010 as one of the best places in the U.S. for college graduates looking for a job.[[88]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-DBJ_city_ranking-93)[[89]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-daytondailynews.com-94) Companies such as [Reynolds and Reynolds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reynolds_and_Reynolds "Reynolds and Reynolds"), [Stratacache](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Stratacache&action=edit&redlink=1 "Stratacache (page does not exist)"), [CareSource](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CareSource "CareSource"), [DP&L (soon AES inc)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DPL_Inc. "DPL Inc."), [LexisNexis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LexisNexis "LexisNexis"), [Kettering Health Network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kettering_Health_Network "Kettering Health Network"), [Premier Health Partners](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Premier_Health_Partners "Premier Health Partners"), and [Standard Register](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Standard_Register "Standard Register") have their headquarters in Dayton. It is also the former home of the [Speedwell Motor Car Company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Speedwell_Motor_Car_Company "Speedwell Motor Car Company"), [MeadWestvaco](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MeadWestvaco "MeadWestvaco") (formerly known as the [Mead Paper Company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mead_Paper_Company "Mead Paper Company")), and [NCR](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NCR_Corporation "NCR Corporation"). NCR was headquartered in Dayton for over 125 years and was a major innovator in computer technology.[[90]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-95)

### Research and development

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Dayton,_Ohio&action=edit&section=22 "Edit section: Research and development")]

[![Image 24](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Kettering_tower.JPG/250px-Kettering_tower.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Kettering_tower.JPG)

[Stratacache Tower](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stratacache_Tower "Stratacache Tower"), Dayton's tallest high-rise

The Dayton region gave birth to aviation[[91]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-96) and is known for its high concentration of [aerospace](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aerospace "Aerospace") and aviation technology. In 2009, Governor [Ted Strickland](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ted_Strickland "Ted Strickland") designated Dayton as Ohio's aerospace innovation hub, the state's first such technology hub.[[92]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-97) Two major United States research and development organizations have leveraged Dayton's historical leadership in aviation and maintain their headquarters in the area: The [National Air and Space Intelligence Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Air_and_Space_Intelligence_Center "National Air and Space Intelligence Center") (NASIC) and the [Air Force Research Laboratory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_Force_Research_Laboratory "Air Force Research Laboratory") (AFRL).[[93]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-98) Both have their headquarters at [Wright-Patterson Air Force Base](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wright-Patterson_Air_Force_Base "Wright-Patterson Air Force Base").[[94]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-99)

Several research organizations support NASIC, AFRL, and the Dayton community. The [Advanced Technical Intelligence Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Advanced_Technical_Intelligence_Center "Advanced Technical Intelligence Center") is a confederation of government, academic, and industry partners. The [University of Dayton Research Institute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Dayton_Research_Institute "University of Dayton Research Institute") (UDRI) is led by the University of Dayton. The Cognitive Technologies Division (CTD) of Applied Research Associates, Inc., which carries out human-centered research and design, is headquartered in the Dayton suburb of Fairborn. The city of Dayton has started [Tech Town](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tech_Town_(Dayton) "Tech Town (Dayton)"), a development project to attract technology-based firms and revitalize the downtown area. Tech Town is home to the world's first [RFID](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RFID "RFID")[business incubator](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Business_incubator "Business incubator").[[95]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-100) The University of Dayton–led Institute for Development & Commercialization of Sensor Technologies (IDCAST) at TechTown is a center for remote sensing and sensing technology. It is one of Dayton's technology business incubators housed in The Entrepreneurs Center building.[[96]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-101)

[![Image 25](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/MVH_Southeast_Tower.JPG/250px-MVH_Southeast_Tower.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:MVH_Southeast_Tower.JPG)

Southeast tower at [Miami Valley Hospital](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miami_Valley_Hospital "Miami Valley Hospital"), part of the [Premier Health Partners](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Premier_Health_Partners "Premier Health Partners") network

The [Kettering Health Network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kettering_Health_Network "Kettering Health Network") and [Premier Health Partners](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Premier_Health_Partners "Premier Health Partners") have a major role on the Dayton area's economy. [Hospitals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hospital "Hospital") in the Greater Dayton area have an estimated combined employment of nearly 32,000 and a yearly economic impact of $6.8 billion.[[13]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-Dayton_area_hospitals-13) In addition, several Dayton area hospitals consistently earn top national ranking and recognition including the _[U.S. News & World Report](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S.\_News\_%26\_World\_Report "U.S. News & World Report")_'s list of "America's Best Hospitals" as well as many of HealthGrades top ratings.[[97]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-102) The most notable hospitals are [Miami Valley Hospital](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miami_Valley_Hospital "Miami Valley Hospital") and [Kettering Medical Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kettering_Medical_Center "Kettering Medical Center").

The Dayton region has several key institutes and centers for health care. The [Center for Tissue Regeneration and Engineering at Dayton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Center_for_Tissue_Regeneration_and_Engineering_at_Dayton "Center for Tissue Regeneration and Engineering at Dayton") focuses on the science and development of human tissue regeneration. The [National Center for Medical Readiness](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Center_for_Medical_Readiness "National Center for Medical Readiness") (NCMR) is also in the Dayton area. The center includes Calamityville, which is a disaster training facility. Over five years, Calamityville is estimated to have a regional economic impact of $374 million.[[98]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-103) Also, the Neurological Institute at Miami Valley Hospital is an institute focused on the diagnosis, treatment, and research of neurological disorders.

According to the city's 2019 Comprehensive Annual Financial Report,[[99]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-104) the top employers in the [city proper](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/City_proper "City proper") are:

[![Image 26](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b6/Schustercenter.jpg/250px-Schustercenter.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Schustercenter.jpg)

The interior of the [Benjamin and Marian Schuster Performing Arts Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benjamin_and_Marian_Schuster_Performing_Arts_Center "Benjamin and Marian Schuster Performing Arts Center")

The Dayton Region ranked within the top 10% in the nation in [arts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arts "Arts") and culture.[[100]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-105) In a 2012 readers' poll by _American Style_ magazine, Dayton ranked #2 in the country among mid-size cities as an arts destination, ranking higher than larger cities such as Atlanta, St. Louis, and Cincinnati.[[101]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-106)[[102]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-107) Dayton is the home of the [Dayton Art Institute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Art_Institute "Dayton Art Institute").

The [Benjamin and Marian Schuster Performing Arts Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benjamin_and_Marian_Schuster_Performing_Arts_Center "Benjamin and Marian Schuster Performing Arts Center") in downtown Dayton is a world-class performing arts center and the home venue of the [Dayton Philharmonic Orchestra](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Philharmonic_Orchestra "Dayton Philharmonic Orchestra"), [Dayton Opera](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Opera "Dayton Opera"), and the [Dayton Ballet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Ballet "Dayton Ballet").[[103]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-108) In addition to [philharmonic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Philharmonic "Philharmonic") and opera performances, the Schuster Center hosts concerts, lectures, and traveling Broadway shows, and is a popular spot for [weddings](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wedding "Wedding") and other events.[[104]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-109) The historic [Victoria Theatre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Victoria_Theatre_(Dayton,_Ohio) "Victoria Theatre (Dayton, Ohio)") in downtown Dayton hosts [concerts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Concert "Concert"), traveling Broadway shows, ballet, a summertime classic film series, and more. The Loft Theatre, also downtown, is the home of the Human Race Theatre Company.[[105]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-110) The Dayton Playhouse, in West Dayton, is the site of numerous plays and theatrical productions.[[106]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-111) Between 1957 and 1995, the [Kenley Players](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kenley_Players "Kenley Players") presented live theater productions in Dayton.[[107]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-kenplayhist_dtn-112)[[108]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-pdobit-113) In 2013, [John Kenley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_Kenley "John Kenley") was inducted into the Dayton Theatre Hall of Fame.[[109]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-daytony-114) Dayton is also home to the [Winter Guard International](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Winter_Guard_International "Winter Guard International") world finals, hosting finals for [winter guard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Winter_guard "Winter guard"), [indoor percussion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indoor_percussion_ensemble "Indoor percussion ensemble"), and indoor winds.[[110]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-115)

Dayton is the home to several ballet companies including:

*   The [Dayton Ballet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Ballet "Dayton Ballet"), one of the oldest professional dance companies in the United States.[[111]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-116) The Dayton Ballet runs the [Dayton Ballet School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Ballet_School "Dayton Ballet School"), the oldest [dance school](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dance_school "Dance school") in Dayton and one of the oldest in the country.[[112]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-117) It is the only ballet school in the [Miami Valley](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miami_Valley "Miami Valley") associated with a professional [dance company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dance_company "Dance company").[[113]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-118)
*   The [Dayton Contemporary Dance Company](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Contemporary_Dance_Company "Dayton Contemporary Dance Company") (established in 1968), which hosts the largest repertory of African-American-based contemporary dance in the world.[_[who?](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual\_of\_Style/Words\_to\_watch#Unsupported\_attributions "Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch")_] The company travels nationally and internationally and has been recognized by critics worldwide.[_[who?](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual\_of\_Style/Words\_to\_watch#Unsupported\_attributions "Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch")_]

Front Street, the largest artists' collective in Dayton, is housed in three industrial buildings on East Second Street.[[114]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-119)[[115]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-120)[[116]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-121)

[![Image 27](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1c/Dayton_Air_Show_2009.jpg/250px-Dayton_Air_Show_2009.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Dayton_Air_Show_2009.jpg)

[Thunderbirds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Air_Force_Thunderbirds "United States Air Force Thunderbirds") at the 2009 [Dayton Air Show](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Air_Show "Dayton Air Show")

The [Vectren Dayton Air Show](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vectren_Dayton_Air_Show "Vectren Dayton Air Show") is an annual [air show](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_show "Air show") that takes place at the [Dayton International Airport](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_International_Airport "Dayton International Airport"). The Vectren Dayton Airshow is one of the largest air shows in the United States.[[117]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-122)

The Dayton area is served by [Five Rivers MetroParks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Five_Rivers_MetroParks "Five Rivers MetroParks"), encompassing 14,161 acres (5,731 ha) over 23 facilities for year-round recreation, education, and conservation.[[118]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-123) In cooperation with the [Miami Conservancy District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miami_Conservancy_District "Miami Conservancy District"), the MetroParks maintains over 70 miles (113 km) of paved, multi-use scenic trails that connect Montgomery County with Greene, Miami, Warren, and Butler counties.[[119]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-Regional_Trails-124)[[120]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-Recreation_Trails-125)

Dayton was home to a thriving [funk](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Funk "Funk") music scene from the 1970s to the early 1980s, that included bands such as [Ohio Players](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ohio_Players "Ohio Players"), [Roger Troutman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roger_Troutman "Roger Troutman")&[Zapp](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zapp_(band) "Zapp (band)"), [Lakeside](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lakeside_(band) "Lakeside (band)"), [Sun](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sun_(R%26B_band) "Sun (R&B band)"), [Dayton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_(band) "Dayton (band)"), [Heatwave](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Heatwave_(band) "Heatwave (band)"), and [Slave](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slave_(band) "Slave (band)").[[121]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-126)

Dayton was also the birthplace to several influential indie and punk bands such as [The Breeders](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Breeders "The Breeders"), [Guided by Voices](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Guided_by_Voices "Guided by Voices"), and [Brainiac](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brainiac_(band) "Brainiac (band)").[[122]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-127)

From 1996 to 1998, Dayton hosted the [National Folk Festival](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Folk_Festival_(USA) "National Folk Festival (USA)"). Since then, the annual Cityfolk Festival has continued to bring folk, ethnic, and world music and arts to Dayton. The Five Rivers MetroParks also owns and operates the [PNC Second Street Market](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PNC_Second_Street_Market "PNC Second Street Market") near downtown Dayton.[[123]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-128)

The Dayton area hosts several arenas and venues. South of Dayton in [Kettering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kettering,_Ohio "Kettering, Ohio") is the [Fraze Pavilion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fraze_Pavilion "Fraze Pavilion"), whose notable performances have included the [Backstreet Boys](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backstreet_Boys "Backstreet Boys"), [Boston](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boston_(band) "Boston (band)"), and [Steve Miller Band](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Steve_Miller_Band "Steve Miller Band").[[124]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-129) South of downtown, on the banks of the [Great Miami River](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Miami_River "Great Miami River"), is the [University of Dayton Arena](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Dayton_Arena "University of Dayton Arena"), home venue for the [University of Dayton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Dayton "University of Dayton") Flyers basketball teams and the location of various other events and [concerts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Concert "Concert").[[125]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-130) It also hosts the [Winter Guard International](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Winter_Guard_International "Winter Guard International") championships, at which hundreds of percussion and color guard ensembles from around the world compete.[[126]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-131) In addition, the Dayton Amateur Radio Association hosts the annual [Dayton Hamvention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Hamvention "Dayton Hamvention"), North America's largest [hamfest](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hamfest "Hamfest"), at the Greene County Fairgrounds in nearby [Xenia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xenia,_Ohio "Xenia, Ohio"). The [Nutter Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nutter_Center "Nutter Center"), which is just east of Dayton in the suburb of [Fairborn](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fairborn,_Ohio "Fairborn, Ohio"), is the home arena for athletics of [Wright State University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wright_State_University "Wright State University") and the former [Dayton Bombers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Bombers "Dayton Bombers") hockey team. This venue is used for many concerts, community events, and various national traveling shows and performances.[[127]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-132)

The [Oregon District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oregon_District "Oregon District") is a historic residential and commercial district in southeast downtown Dayton. The district is populated with [art galleries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art_galleries "Art galleries"), [specialty shops](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Specialty_shops "Specialty shops"), [pubs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pubs "Pubs"), [nightclubs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nightclubs "Nightclubs"), and [coffee houses](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coffee_houses "Coffee houses").[[128]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-133)

The city of Dayton is also host to yearly [festivals](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Festivals "Festivals"), such as the Dayton Celtic Festival,[[129]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-134) the Dayton Blues Festival, Dayton Music Fest, Urban Nights, Women in Jazz, the African American and Cultural Festival, the Dayton Reggae Fest, and the Dayton Hispanic Heritage Festival.[[130]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-135)[[131]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-136)

The city's fine dining restaurants include [The Pine Club](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Pine_Club "The Pine Club"), a nationally known steakhouse.[[132]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-schuster2011-137)[[133]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-500things-138)[[134]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-ddn0714-139)[[135]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-140)

[![Image 28](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Marion%27s_Supreme.JPG/250px-Marion%27s_Supreme.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Marion%27s_Supreme.JPG)

Dayton-style pizza

Dayton is home to a variety of [pizza chains](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pizzeria "Pizzeria") that have become woven into local culture, the most notable of which are [Cassano's](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cassano%27s "Cassano's") and [Marion's Piazza](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marion%27s_Piazza "Marion's Piazza"), both of which produce [Dayton-style pizza](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton-style_pizza "Dayton-style pizza"), which has a thin, crisp, salty crust dusted on the bottom with [cornmeal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cornmeal "Cornmeal") and topped with a thin layer of thick unsweetened sauce. Cheese and other topping ingredients are heavily distributed and spread edge-to-edge with no outer rim of crust, and the finished pizza is cut into bite-size squares.[[136]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-:0-141)[[137]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-:1-142)[[138]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-:2-143)[[139]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-:5-144)

Notable Dayton-based restaurant chains include [Hot Head Burritos](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hot_Head_Burritos "Hot Head Burritos").[[140]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-145)

In addition to restaurants, the city is also home to [Esther Price Candies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Esther_Price_Candies "Esther Price Candies"),[[141]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-146) a candy and chocolate company, and [Mike-sells](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike-sells "Mike-sells"), the oldest potato chip company in the United States.[[142]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-147)

The city began developing a reputation for its number of [breweries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Brewery "Brewery") and [craft beer](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Craft_beer "Craft beer") venues by the late 2010s.[[143]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-148)[[144]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-149)

Many major religions are represented in Dayton. Christianity is represented in Dayton by dozens of denominations and their respective churches.[[145]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-150) Notable Dayton churches include the [First Lutheran Church](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/First_Lutheran_Church_(Dayton,_Ohio) "First Lutheran Church (Dayton, Ohio)"), [Sacred Heart Church](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sacred_Heart_Church_(Dayton,_Ohio) "Sacred Heart Church (Dayton, Ohio)"), and [Ginghamsburg Church](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ginghamsburg_Church "Ginghamsburg Church"). Dayton's [Muslim](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Muslim "Muslim") community is largely represented by the [Islamic Society of Greater Dayton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Islamic_Society_of_Greater_Dayton "Islamic Society of Greater Dayton") (ISGD), a Muslim community that includes a mosque on Josie Street. Dayton is also home to the [United Theological Seminary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Theological_Seminary "United Theological Seminary"), one of 13 seminaries affiliated with the [United Methodist Church](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Methodist_Church "United Methodist Church"). [Judaism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Judaism "Judaism") is represented by [Temple Israel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Temple_Israel_(Dayton,_Ohio) "Temple Israel (Dayton, Ohio)"). Hinduism is represented by the [Hindu Temple of Dayton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hindu_Temple_of_Dayton "Hindu Temple of Dayton").[[146]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-151)[Old North Dayton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Old_North_Dayton,_Dayton,_Ohio "Old North Dayton, Dayton, Ohio") also has a number of Catholic churches built by immigrants from Lithuania, Poland, Hungary, and Germany.

[![Image 29](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/57/Wright_Brothers_Bike_Shop_2_Dayton_Ohio.jpg/250px-Wright_Brothers_Bike_Shop_2_Dayton_Ohio.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Wright_Brothers_Bike_Shop_2_Dayton_Ohio.jpg)

[Dayton Aviation Heritage National Historical Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Aviation_Heritage_National_Historical_Park "Dayton Aviation Heritage National Historical Park")

Tourism also accounts for one out of every 14 private sector jobs in the county. Tourism in the Dayton region is led by the [National Museum of the United States Air Force](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Museum_of_the_United_States_Air_Force "National Museum of the United States Air Force") at [Wright-Patterson Air Force Base](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wright-Patterson_Air_Force_Base "Wright-Patterson Air Force Base"), the largest and oldest military aviation museum in the world.[[147]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-152) The museum draws over 1.3 million visitors per year and is one of the most-visited tourist attractions in Ohio.[[148]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-153)[[149]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-154) The museum houses the [National Aviation Hall of Fame](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Aviation_Hall_of_Fame "National Aviation Hall of Fame").

Other museums also play significant roles in the tourism and economy of the Dayton area. The [Dayton Art Institute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Art_Institute "Dayton Art Institute"), a museum of fine arts, owns collections containing more than 20,000 objects spanning 5,000 years of art and archaeological history.[[150]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-155) The Dayton Art Institute was rated one of the top 10 best art museums in the United States for children.[[151]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-156) The [Boonshoft Museum of Discovery](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boonshoft_Museum_of_Discovery "Boonshoft Museum of Discovery") is a [children's museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Children%27s_museum "Children's museum") of science with numerous exhibits, one of which includes an indoor [zoo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zoo "Zoo") with nearly 100 different animals.[[152]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-157)

There are also some notable historical museums in the region. The [Dayton Aviation Heritage National Historical Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Aviation_Heritage_National_Historical_Park "Dayton Aviation Heritage National Historical Park"), operated by the [National Park Service](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Park_Service "National Park Service"), commemorates the lives and achievements of Dayton natives [Orville](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orville_Wright "Orville Wright") and [Wilbur Wright](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilbur_Wright "Wilbur Wright") and [Paul Laurence Dunbar](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Paul_Laurence_Dunbar "Paul Laurence Dunbar"). The Wright brothers' famous [Wright Flyer III](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wright_Flyer_III "Wright Flyer III") aircraft is housed in a museum at [Carillon Historical Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carillon_Historical_Park "Carillon Historical Park"). Dayton is also home to [America's Packard Museum](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/America%27s_Packard_Museum "America's Packard Museum"), which contains many restored historical [Packard](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Packard "Packard") vehicles.[[153]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-158)[SunWatch Indian Village/Archaeological Park](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SunWatch_Indian_Village "SunWatch Indian Village"), a partially reconstructed 12th-century prehistoric [American Indian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Indigenous_people_of_the_Americas "Indigenous people of the Americas") village, is on the south end of Dayton; it is organized around a central plaza dominated by wood posts forming an astronomical calendar. The park includes a museum where visitors can learn about the Indian history of the Miami Valley.[[154]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-159)

Parks and recreation
--------------------

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Dayton,_Ohio&action=edit&section=31 "Edit section: Parks and recreation")]

Dayton was named National Geographic's outdoor adventure capital of the Midwest in 2019 due in large part to the metropolitan area's revitalized Five Rivers MetroPark, extensive bicycle and jogging trail system, urban green spaces, lakes and camping areas.[[155]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-160)

[![Image 30](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/0b/Montgomery_County_OH_USA_Recreation_Trail_Map.jpg/250px-Montgomery_County_OH_USA_Recreation_Trail_Map.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Montgomery_County_OH_USA_Recreation_Trail_Map.jpg)

Dayton Regional Bike Trail Map[[156]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-161)

In cooperation with the [Miami Conservancy District](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miami_Conservancy_District "Miami Conservancy District"), [Five Rivers MetroParks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Five_Rivers_MetroParks "Five Rivers MetroParks") hosts 340 miles of paved trails, the largest network of paved off-street trails in the United States.[[157]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-162)[[119]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-Regional_Trails-124)[[120]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-Recreation_Trails-125) The regional trail system represents over 35% of the 900 miles in Ohio's off-street trail network.[[158]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-163) In 2010, the city of [Troy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Troy,_Ohio "Troy, Ohio") was named "[bike friendly](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bicycle-friendly "Bicycle-friendly")" by the [League of American Bicyclists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/League_of_American_Bicyclists "League of American Bicyclists"), which gave the city the organization's bronze designation.[[159]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-Bike_friendly-164) The honorable mention made Dayton one of two cities in Ohio to receive the award, the other being Columbus, and one of 15 cities nationwide.[[159]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-Bike_friendly-164)

The Dayton area is home to several minor league and semi pro teams, as well as NCAA Division I sports programs.

The [Dayton Dragons](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Dragons "Dayton Dragons") professional baseball team is a Class A minor league affiliate for the [Cincinnati Reds](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cincinnati_Reds "Cincinnati Reds"). The Dayton Dragons are the first (and only) team in [minor league baseball](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Minor_league_baseball "Minor league baseball") history to sell out an entire season before it began and was voted as one of the top 10 hottest tickets to get in all of professional sports by [Sports Illustrated](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sports_Illustrated "Sports Illustrated").[[160]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-165) The Dayton Dragons 815 consecutive sellouts surpassed the NBA's [Portland Trail Blazers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Portland_Trail_Blazers "Portland Trail Blazers") for the longest sellout streak across all professional sports in the U.S.[[35]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-DragonsSellout-35)[[161]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-166)

[![Image 31](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/University_of_Dayton_Arena.jpg/250px-University_of_Dayton_Arena.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:University_of_Dayton_Arena.jpg)

[UD Arena](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UD_Arena "UD Arena") during a [Dayton Flyers men's basketball](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Flyers_men%27s_basketball "Dayton Flyers men's basketball") game in 2016

The [University of Dayton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Dayton "University of Dayton") and [Wright State University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wright_State_University "Wright State University") both host [NCAA](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NCAA "NCAA") basketball. The [University of Dayton Arena](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Dayton_Arena "University of Dayton Arena") has hosted more games in the [NCAA men's basketball tournament](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NCAA_Men%27s_Division_I_Basketball_Championship "NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship") over its history than any other venue.[[162]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-167) UD Arena is also the site of the First Round games of the NCAA Tournament. In 2012, eight teams competed for the final four spots in the NCAA basketball tournament. Wright State University's NCAA men's basketball is the [Wright State Raiders](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wright_State_Raiders "Wright State Raiders") and the University of Dayton's NCAA men's basketball team is the [Dayton Flyers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Flyers "Dayton Flyers").

The Dayton Gems were a minor league [ice hockey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ice_hockey "Ice hockey") team in the [International Hockey League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Hockey_League_(1945%E2%80%932001) "International Hockey League (1945–2001)") from 1964 to 1977, 1979 to 1980, and most recently 2009 to 2012. The [Dayton Bombers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Bombers "Dayton Bombers") were an [ECHL](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/East_Coast_Hockey_League "East Coast Hockey League")[ice hockey](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ice_hockey "Ice hockey") team from 1991 to 2009. They most recently played the North Division of the ECHL's American Conference. In June 2009, it was announced the Bombers would turn in their membership back to the league.[[163]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-168)

Despite the folding of the Bombers, hockey remained in Dayton as the [Dayton Gems](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Gems_(2009%E2%80%93) "Dayton Gems (2009–)") of the [International Hockey League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Hockey_League_(2007-) "International Hockey League (2007-)") were formed in the fall of 2009 at [Hara Arena](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hara_Arena "Hara Arena").[[164]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-169) The Gems folded after the 2011–12 season. Shortly after the Gems folded, it was announced a new team, the [Dayton Demonz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Demonz "Dayton Demonz"), would begin play in 2012 in the [Federal Hockey League](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Hockey_League "Federal Hockey League") (FHL). The Demonz folded in 2015 and were immediately replaced by the [Dayton Demolition](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Demolition "Dayton Demolition"), also in the FHL. However, the Demolition would cease operations after only one season[[165]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-DaytonDone-170) when [Hara Arena](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hara_Arena "Hara Arena") decided to close due to financial difficulties.[[166]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-171)

Dayton hosted the first American Professional Football Association game (precursor to the [NFL](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Football_League "National Football League")). The game was played at Triangle Park between the [Dayton Triangles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Triangles "Dayton Triangles") and the [Columbus Panhandles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Columbus_Panhandles "Columbus Panhandles") on October 3, 1920, and is considered one of the first professional football games ever played.[[167]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-172) Football teams in the Dayton area include the [Dayton Flyers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Flyers "Dayton Flyers") and the [Dayton Sharks](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Sharks "Dayton Sharks").

The Dayton region is also known for the many golf courses and clubs that it hosts. The [Miami Valley Golf Club](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miami_Valley_Golf_Club "Miami Valley Golf Club"), [Moraine Country Club](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moraine_Country_Club "Moraine Country Club"), [NCR Country Club](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NCR_Country_Club "NCR Country Club"), and the [Pipestone Golf Course](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Pipestone_Golf_Course&action=edit&redlink=1 "Pipestone Golf Course (page does not exist)") are some of the more notable courses. Also, several PGA Championships have been held at area golf courses. The Miami Valley Golf Club hosted the [1957 PGA Championship](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1957_PGA_Championship "1957 PGA Championship"), the Moraine Country Club hosted the [1945 PGA Championship](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1945_PGA_Championship "1945 PGA Championship"), and the NCR Country club hosted the [1969 PGA Championship](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1969_PGA_Championship "1969 PGA Championship"). Additionally, NCR CC hosted the 1986 U.S. Women's Open, the 2005 U.S. Senior Open, the 2013 State Team Championships and most recently the 2022 Senior Women's Open. Other notable courses include the Yankee Trace Golf Club, the Beavercreek Golf Club, Dayton Meadowbrook Country Club, Sycamore Creek Country Club, Heatherwoode Golf Club, Community Golf Course, and Kitty Hawk Golf Course.[[168]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-173)

The city of Dayton is the home to the [Dayton Area Rugby Club](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Area_Rugby_Club "Dayton Area Rugby Club") which hosts their home games at the [Dayton Rugby Grounds](https://www.google.com/maps/place/Dayton+Rugby+Grounds/@39.8240283,-84.2286685,17z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m5!3m4!1s0x884081cca0a9e807:0x6cc508b8ef9ae78c!8m2!3d39.8240242!4d-84.2264798). As of 2018, the club fields two men's and one women's side for [Rugby Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rugby_union "Rugby union") and several [Rugby Sevens](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rugby_sevens "Rugby sevens") sides. The club also hosts the annual Gem City 7's tournament.

The Dayton City Commission is composed of the mayor and four city commissioners. Each city commission member is elected at-large on a non-partisan basis for four-year, overlapping terms. All policy items are decided by the city commission, which is empowered by the City Charter to pass ordinances and resolutions, adopt regulations, and appoint the city manager. The city manager is responsible for budgeting and implementing policies and initiatives. Dayton was the first large American city to adopt the city manager ([Henry Matson Waite](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Henry_Matson_Waite_(engineer) "Henry Matson Waite (engineer)")) form of municipal government, in 1913.[[169]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-174)[[170]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-TechWorld-175)

[Dayton Public Schools](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Public_Schools,_Montgomery_County,_Ohio "Dayton Public Schools, Montgomery County, Ohio") operates 34 schools that serve 16,855 students,[[171]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-176) including:

*   [Belmont High](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Belmont_High_School_(Ohio) "Belmont High School (Ohio)")
*   [Meadowdale High](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Meadowdale_High_School_(Ohio) "Meadowdale High School (Ohio)")
*   [Paul Laurence Dunbar High](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dunbar_High_School_(Ohio) "Dunbar High School (Ohio)")
*   [Ponitz Career Technology Center](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ponitz_Career_Technology_Center "Ponitz Career Technology Center")
*   [Stivers School for the Arts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stivers_School_for_the_Arts "Stivers School for the Arts")
*   [Thurgood Marshall High](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thurgood_Marshall_High_School_(Dayton,_Ohio) "Thurgood Marshall High School (Dayton, Ohio)")

The city of Dayton has more than 35 private schools within the city,[[172]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-177) including:

*   [Archbishop Alter High School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Archbishop_Alter_High_School "Archbishop Alter High School")
*   [Carroll High School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carroll_High_School_(Dayton,_Ohio) "Carroll High School (Dayton, Ohio)")
*   [Chaminade Julienne Catholic High School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chaminade_Julienne_Catholic_High_School "Chaminade Julienne Catholic High School")
*   [Dayton Christian School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Christian_School "Dayton Christian School")
*   [Dominion Academy of Dayton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dominion_Academy_of_Dayton "Dominion Academy of Dayton")
*   [The Miami Valley School](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Miami_Valley_School "The Miami Valley School")
*   [Spring Valley Academy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spring_Valley_Academy "Spring Valley Academy")
*   [Reformation Classical Academy](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Reformation_Classical_Academy&action=edit&redlink=1 "Reformation Classical Academy (page does not exist)")

Dayton has 33 [charter schools](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charter_school "Charter school").[[173]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-178) Three of the top five charter schools named in 2011 are K–8 schools managed by [National Heritage Academies](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Heritage_Academies "National Heritage Academies").[[174]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-179) Notable charter schools include:

*   [Dayton Early College Academy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Early_College_Academy "Dayton Early College Academy")
*   [Emerson Academy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emerson_Academy "Emerson Academy")
*   [North Dayton School of Discovery](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/North_Dayton_School_of_Discovery "North Dayton School of Discovery")
*   [Pathway School of Discovery](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pathway_School_of_Discovery "Pathway School of Discovery")
*   [Richard Allen Schools](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richard_Allen_Schools "Richard Allen Schools")

### Colleges and universities

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Dayton,_Ohio&action=edit&section=38 "Edit section: Colleges and universities")]

[![Image 32](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/UniversityofDayton.jpg/250px-UniversityofDayton.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:UniversityofDayton.jpg)

St. Mary's Hall and the Immaculate Conception Chapel at the University of Dayton

The Dayton area was ranked tenth for higher education among [metropolitan areas](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metropolitan_area "Metropolitan area") in the United States by _[Forbes](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Forbes "Forbes")_ in 2009.[[175]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-180) The city is home to two major universities. The [University of Dayton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Dayton "University of Dayton") is a private, [Catholic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Church "Roman Catholic Church") institution founded in 1850 by the [Marianist order](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Society_of_Mary_(Marianists) "Society of Mary (Marianists)"). It has the only [American Bar Association](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Bar_Association "American Bar Association") (ABA)-approved [law school](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law_school "Law school") in the Dayton area.[[176]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-181) The University of Dayton is Ohio's largest [private university](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Private_university "Private university") and is also home to the [University of Dayton Research Institute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/University_of_Dayton_Research_Institute "University of Dayton Research Institute"), which ranks third in the nation for sponsored materials research,[[177]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-182) and the [Center for Tissue Regeneration and Engineering at Dayton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Center_for_Tissue_Regeneration_and_Engineering_at_Dayton "Center for Tissue Regeneration and Engineering at Dayton"), which focuses on human tissue regeneration.[[178]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-183)

The public [Wright State University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wright_State_University "Wright State University") became a state university in 1967. Wright State University established the [National Center for Medical Readiness](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_Center_for_Medical_Readiness "National Center for Medical Readiness"), a national training program for disaster preparedness and relief. Wright State's [Boonshoft School of Medicine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boonshoft_School_of_Medicine "Boonshoft School of Medicine") is the Dayton area's only medical school and is a leader in [biomedical research](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biomedical_research "Biomedical research").[[179]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-184)

Dayton is also home to [Sinclair Community College](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sinclair_Community_College "Sinclair Community College"), the largest [community college](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Community_college "Community college") at a single location in Ohio[[180]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-185) and one of the nation's largest community colleges.[[181]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-186) Sinclair is acclaimed as one of the country's best community colleges.[[182]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-187) Sinclair was founded as the YMCA college in 1887.

Other schools just outside Dayton that shape the educational landscape are [Antioch College](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antioch_College "Antioch College") and [Antioch University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Antioch_University "Antioch University"), both in [Yellow Springs](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Yellow_Springs,_Ohio "Yellow Springs, Ohio"), [Central State University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_State_University "Central State University") in [Wilberforce](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wilberforce,_Ohio "Wilberforce, Ohio"), [Kettering College of Medical Arts](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kettering_College_of_Medical_Arts "Kettering College of Medical Arts") and [School of Advertising Art](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/School_of_Advertising_Art "School of Advertising Art") in [Kettering](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kettering,_Ohio "Kettering, Ohio"), [DeVry University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/DeVry_University "DeVry University") in [Beavercreek](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beavercreek,_Ohio "Beavercreek, Ohio"), [Cedarville University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cedarville_University "Cedarville University"), [Clark State Community College](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clark_State_Community_College "Clark State Community College") and [Wittenberg University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wittenberg_University "Wittenberg University") in [Springfield](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Springfield,_Ohio "Springfield, Ohio"). The [Air Force Institute of Technology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Air_Force_Institute_of_Technology "Air Force Institute of Technology"), which was founded in 1919 and serves as a graduate school for the [United States Air Force](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Air_Force "United States Air Force"), is at the nearby [Wright-Patterson Air Force Base](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wright-Patterson_Air_Force_Base "Wright-Patterson Air Force Base").

*   [Boonshoft School of Medicine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boonshoft_School_of_Medicine "Boonshoft School of Medicine")
*   [Dayton Art Institute](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Art_Institute "Dayton Art Institute")
*   [Ohio Institute of Photography and Technology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ohio_Institute_of_Photography_and_Technology "Ohio Institute of Photography and Technology")
*   [School of Advertising Art](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/School_of_Advertising_Art "School of Advertising Art")
*   [Wright State University](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wright_State_University "Wright State University")

[![Image 33](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/1/1f/New_Dayton_Daily_News_Building.jpg/250px-New_Dayton_Daily_News_Building.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:New_Dayton_Daily_News_Building.jpg)

Dayton Daily News building at 1611 S. Main St.

Dayton is served in print by _[The Dayton Daily News](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Dayton\_Daily\_News "The Dayton Daily News")_, the city's sole remaining daily newspaper. The _Dayton Daily News_ is owned by [Cox Enterprises](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cox_Enterprises "Cox Enterprises"). The Dayton region's main business newspaper is the _[Dayton Business Journal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton\_Business\_Journal "Dayton Business Journal")_. The _Dayton City Paper,_ a [community paper](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Community_paper "Community paper") focused on music, art, and independent thought ceased operation in 2018. _The Dayton Weekly News_ has been published since 1993, providing news and information to Dayton's African-American community.

There are numerous magazines produced in and for the Dayton region. _The Dayton Magazine_ provides insight into arts, food, and events. _Focus on Business_ is published by the Chamber of Commerce to provide awareness of companies and initiatives affecting the regional economy

[Nielsen Media Research](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nielsen_Media_Research "Nielsen Media Research") ranked the 11-county Dayton [television market](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Media_market "Media market") as the No. 62 market in the United States.[[183]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-188) The market is served by stations affiliated with major American networks including: [WDTN](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WDTN "WDTN"), channel 2 – [NBC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NBC "NBC"), operated by [Nexstar Media Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nexstar_Media_Group "Nexstar Media Group"); [WHIO-TV](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WHIO-TV "WHIO-TV"), channel 7 – [CBS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CBS "CBS"), operated by [Cox Media Group](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cox_Media_Group "Cox Media Group"); [WPTD](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WPTD "WPTD"), channel 16 – [PBS](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_Broadcasting_Service "Public Broadcasting Service"), operated by [ThinkTV](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ThinkTV "ThinkTV"), which also operates [WPTO](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WPTO "WPTO"), assigned to [Oxford](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oxford,_Ohio "Oxford, Ohio"); [WKEF](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WKEF "WKEF"), channel 22 – [ABC](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company "American Broadcasting Company")/[Fox](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Broadcasting_Company "Fox Broadcasting Company"), operated by [Sinclair Broadcasting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sinclair_Broadcasting "Sinclair Broadcasting"); [WBDT](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WBDT "WBDT"), channel 26 – [The CW](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_CW "The CW"), operated by [Vaughan Media](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vaughan_Media "Vaughan Media") (a [shell corporation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shell_corporation "Shell corporation") of Nexstar), assigned to [Springfield](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Springfield,_Ohio "Springfield, Ohio"); [WKOI-TV](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WKOI-TV "WKOI-TV"), channel 43 – [Ion Television](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ion_Television "Ion Television"), assigned to [Richmond, Indiana](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Richmond,_Indiana "Richmond, Indiana"); and [WRGT-TV](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WRGT-TV "WRGT-TV"), channel 45 – [My Network TV](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/My_Network_TV "My Network TV"), operated under a local marketing agreement by [Sinclair Broadcasting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sinclair_Broadcasting "Sinclair Broadcasting"). The nationally syndicated morning talk show _[The Daily Buzz](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The\_Daily\_Buzz "The Daily Buzz")_ originated from WBDT, the former [ACME Communications](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ACME_Communications "ACME Communications") property in [Miamisburg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miamisburg,_Ohio "Miamisburg, Ohio"), before moving to its current home in Florida.

Dayton is also served by 42 [AM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AM_broadcasting "AM broadcasting") and [FM](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FM_broadcasting "FM broadcasting") radio stations directly, and numerous other stations are heard from elsewhere in southwest Ohio, which serve outlying suburbs and adjoining counties.[[184]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-189)

[![Image 34](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bc/City_Railway_Company_%28of_Dayton_Ohio%29_1899.jpg/250px-City_Railway_Company_%28of_Dayton_Ohio%29_1899.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:City_Railway_Company_(of_Dayton_Ohio)_1899.jpg)

Share of the City Railway Company (of Dayton, Ohio), issued May 2, 1899

The [Greater Dayton Regional Transit Authority](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greater_Dayton_Regional_Transit_Authority "Greater Dayton Regional Transit Authority") (RTA) operates public bus routes in the Dayton metro area. In addition to routes covered by traditional [diesel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diesel_engine "Diesel engine")-powered buses, RTA has several [electric trolley bus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trolleybus "Trolleybus") routes. The [Dayton trolleybus system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trolleybuses_in_Dayton "Trolleybuses in Dayton") is the second longest-running of the four remaining trolleybus systems in the U.S., having entered service in 1933.[[185]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-190) It is the present manifestation of an electric transit service that has operated continuously in Dayton since 1888.

Dayton operates a [Greyhound Station](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Greyhound_Lines "Greyhound Lines") which provides inter-city bus transportation to and from Dayton. The hub is in the Greater Dayton Regional Transit Authority North-West hub in [Trotwood](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trotwood,_Ohio "Trotwood, Ohio").[[186]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-191)

[![Image 35](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3d/Dayton_terminal.JPG/250px-Dayton_terminal.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Dayton_terminal.JPG)

Terminal building at [Dayton International Airport](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_International_Airport "Dayton International Airport")

[Dayton International Airport](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_International_Airport "Dayton International Airport") lies in a northern exclave of the city and offers service to 21 markets through 10 airlines. In 2008, it served 2.9 million passengers. The Dayton International Airport is also a significant regional air freight hub hosting [FedEx Express](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/FedEx_Express "FedEx Express"), [UPS Airlines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UPS_Airlines "UPS Airlines"), [United States Postal Service](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Postal_Service "United States Postal Service"), and major commercial freight carriers.[[187]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-192)

The Dayton area also has several regional airports. The [Dayton–Wright Brothers Airport](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton%E2%80%93Wright_Brothers_Airport "Dayton–Wright Brothers Airport") is a general aviation airport owned by the City of Dayton 10 miles (16 km) south of the central business district of Dayton on [Springboro Pike](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ohio_State_Route_741 "Ohio State Route 741") in [Miami Township](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Miami_Township,_Montgomery_County,_Ohio "Miami Township, Montgomery County, Ohio"). It serves as the [reliever airport](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reliever_airport "Reliever airport") for Dayton International Airport. The airport primarily serves corporate and personal aircraft users.[[188]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-193) The [Dahio Trotwood Airport](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dahio_Trotwood_Airport "Dahio Trotwood Airport"), also known as Dayton-New Lebanon Airport, is a privately owned, public-use airport 7 miles (11 km) west of the central business district of Dayton.[[189]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-194) The [Moraine Airpark](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moraine_Airpark "Moraine Airpark") is a privately owned, public-use airport 4 miles (6.4 km) southwest of the city of Dayton.[[190]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-195)

The Dayton region is primarily served by three interstates:

*   [Interstate 75](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interstate_75 "Interstate 75") runs north to south through the city of Dayton and many of Dayton's north and south suburbs, including Kettering and Centerville south of Dayton and Vandalia, Tipp City, and Troy north of Dayton.
*   [Interstate 70](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interstate_70 "Interstate 70") is a major east–west interstate that runs through many of Dayton's east and west suburbs, including Huber Heights, Butler Township, Englewood, and Brookville, and intersects with I-75 in Vandalia, Ohio, just north of the city. This intersection of I-70 and I-75 is also known as "Freedom Veterans Crossroads", which was officially named by the [U.S. Department of Transportation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._Department_of_Transportation "U.S. Department of Transportation") in 2004.[[191]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-196) I-70 is the major route to the airport.
*   [Interstate 675](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interstate_675_(Ohio) "Interstate 675 (Ohio)") is a partial interstate ring on the southeastern and eastern suburbs of Dayton. It runs northeast to south and connects to I-70 to the northeast and I-75 to the south.

Other major routes for the region include:

*   [US 35](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/US_35 "US 35") is a major limited access east–west highway that bisects the city. It is most widely used between [Drexel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Drexel,_Ohio "Drexel, Ohio") and [Xenia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Xenia,_Ohio "Xenia, Ohio").
*   [Route 40](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/U.S._Route_40 "U.S. Route 40") is a major east–west highway that runs parallel to (and 2 miles north of) I-70
*   [State Route 4](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ohio_State_Route_4 "Ohio State Route 4") is a freeway that is most heavily traveled between I-75 and I-70.
*   [State Route 444](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ohio_State_Route_444 "Ohio State Route 444") is north–south [state highway](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_highway "State highway"). Its southern terminus is at its interchange with Route 4, and its northern terminus is at [Interstate 675](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interstate_675_(Ohio) "Interstate 675 (Ohio)"). This [limited-access road](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Limited-access_road "Limited-access road") serves Dayton and Fairborn and is a significant route to access points serving [Wright-Patterson Air Force Base](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wright-Patterson_Air_Force_Base "Wright-Patterson Air Force Base").

From 2010 through 2017, the [Ohio Department of Transportation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ohio_Department_of_Transportation "Ohio Department of Transportation") (ODOT) performed a $533 million construction project to modify, reconstruct and widen I-75 through downtown Dayton, from Edwin C Moses Blvd. to Stanley Avenue.[[192]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-197)

Dayton hosts several inter-modal freight railroad terminals. Two [Class I railroads](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Class_I_railroads "Class I railroads"), [CSX](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CSX "CSX") and [Norfolk Southern Railway](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Norfolk_Southern_Railway "Norfolk Southern Railway"), operate switching yards in the city.[[193]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-198)

Formerly the [Baltimore and Ohio Railroad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Baltimore_and_Ohio_Railroad "Baltimore and Ohio Railroad"), [New York Central Railroad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_York_Central_Railroad "New York Central Railroad") and the [Pennsylvania Railroad](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pennsylvania_Railroad "Pennsylvania Railroad"), and afterward, [Amtrak](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amtrak "Amtrak") made long-distance passenger train stops at [Dayton Union Station](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton_Union_Station "Dayton Union Station") on S. Sixth Street. The last train leaving there was the _[National Limited](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National\_Limited\_(Amtrak) "National Limited (Amtrak)")_ in October 1979.[[194]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dayton,_Ohio#cite_note-199)

[![Image 36](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/Holon_Twin_cities.JPG/250px-Holon_Twin_cities.JPG)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Holon_Twin_cities.JPG)

The Dayton City Seal (fourth from left) in its sister city of [Holon, Israel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holon "Holon")

*   [Sarajevo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sarajevo "Sarajevo"), [Bosnia and Herzegovina](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bosnia_and_Herzegovina "Bosnia and Herzegovina")
*   [Augsburg](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Augsburg "Augsburg"), [Germany](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Germany "Germany")
*   [Holon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Holon "Holon"), [Israel](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Israel "Israel")
*   [Monrovia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Monrovia "Monrovia"), [Liberia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liberia "Liberia")
*   [Ōiso](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C5%8Ciso "Ōiso"), [Japan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Japan "Japan")
*   [Rushmoor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rushmoor "Rushmoor"), [England](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/England "England")

*   [List of U.S. cities with large Black populations](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_U.S._cities_with_large_Black_populations "List of U.S. cities with large Black populations")

*   [Politics of Dayton, Ohio](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Politics_of_Dayton,_Ohio "Politics of Dayton, Ohio")

*   [_Delco Electronics_ Corporation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delco_Electronics "Delco Electronics")

 Discover the Unexpected 

Welcome to Dayton, Ohio
=======================

Discover the Unexpected in Dayton, Ohio, the Birthplace of Aviation!Dayton and Montgomery County offer big-city amenities with Midwestern charm and affordability.Dayton is home to the[Wright Brothers](https://www.destinationdayton.org/maps-and-info/history/wright-brothers/),the[Dayton Aviation Heritage National Historical Park](https://www.destinationdayton.org/things-to-do/attractions/dayton-aviation-park/), and the[National Museum of the U.S. Air Force](https://www.destinationdayton.org/things-to-do/attractions/air-force-museum/)™, the world’s largest and oldest military aviation museum and the state’s most-visited free tourist attraction!

There's still a lot of summer left in Destination Dayton, from [can't-miss festivals](https://www.destinationdayton.org/blog/post/discover-the-unexpected-daytons-most-delightfully-surprising-festivals/), [outdoor concerts](https://www.destinationdayton.org/blog/post/places-to-see-outdoor-summer-concerts-in-dayton/) and[Dayton Dragons baseball](https://www.destinationdayton.org/things-to-do/dayton-dragons/), to [outdoor adventures](https://www.destinationdayton.org/things-to-do/outdoors/), [unexpected dining](https://www.destinationdayton.org/blog/post/savor-the-flavor-a-foodies-guide-to-dining-in-downtown-dayton/), and unique [attractions](https://www.destinationdayton.org/things-to-do/attractions/)!

[Learn More](https://www.destinationdayton.org/things-to-do/)

![Image 10: downtown Dayton skyline](https://assets.simpleviewinc.com/simpleview/image/upload/c_fill,f_jpg,h_449,q_65,w_640/v1/clients/dayton-redesign/Fountain_of_Lights_unedited_Web1880x1343_c1c42f37-e433-4974-8c4d-ed770cb6cbe4.jpg)The Birthplace Of Aviation

Since 1951, when MIT Lincoln Laboratory was established to build the nation’s first air defense system, the Laboratory has been applying advanced technology to problems critical to national security. In addition to an impressive record of technical innovation in communications, space surveillance, advanced electronics, and air and missile defense, today the Laboratory is also leading the way in newer areas such as cyber security, integrated sensing and decision support and homeland protection. Behind every Laboratory solution are researchers with exceptional technical abilities and imagination, developing systems from the initial concept stage, through simulation and analysis, to design and prototyping, and finally to real world demonstrations. Cross-disciplinary collaboration and the breadth of Lincoln Laboratory’s research enable continuous technical growth for its scientists – and they also inspire unparalleled creativity. In the past six years, MIT Lincoln Laboratory has been awarded 26 R&D 100 Awards that recognize the year’s 100 most significant innovations in technology. 

All positions are located in Lexington, MA. 

www.ll.mit.edu/employment 

MIT Lincoln Laboratory is an Equal Employment Opportunity (EEO) employer. All qualified applicants will receive consideration for employment and will not be discriminated against on the basis of race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, age, veteran status, disability status, or genetic information. Due to the unique nature of our work, we require U.S citizenship.

# 30 The Archives and the Archivist: Sharing SWE’s Story Together 

In addition to being a repository of many “stories” and artifacts, the SWE archives has an interesting story of its own, intertwined with that of SWE’s archivist, Troy Eller English, who oversees the collection. 

# 36 LGBTQ Employment Policy Caught in the Crosscurrents 

Influenced by political advocacy and motivated by a need to attract and retain a diverse, talented workforce, many organizations have adopted LGBTQ nondiscrimination policies. As political and cultural dynamics shift, however, the status of these advancements may come into question. 

# 44 Engineering the Magic of Live Entertainment 

The massive amount of technology that goes into live performance means that nearly every form of live entertainment needs the support of engineers. In fact, the demand for women engineers in this area is rising, presenting unique opportunities. 

# 50 Women Engineers You Should Know 

Women engineers make important contributions to every aspect of contemporary life, frequently with little or no recognition. In keeping with the spirit of Women’s History Month, we present a sampling of women whose work has made a difference and who lead interesting and impactful lives while giving back to their profession and communities. 

Karen Horting, CAE | Executive Director & CEO

ABOUT SWE: 

The Society of Women Engineers (SWE), founded in 1950, is a not-for-profit educational and service organization. SWE is the driving force that establishes engineering as a highly desirable career aspiration for women. SWE empowers women to succeed and advance in those aspirations and be recognized for their life-changing contributions and achievements as women engineers and leaders.

> 7BACK TO TABLE OF CONTENTS |SWE SPRING 2017

# From year to year, the spring issue of SWE 

has had familiar themes. Published in March, a month that includes International Women’s Day on the 8th, plus ongoing women’s history celebrations in the United States and other countries, it’s fitting that we examine policies that affect women, as well as honor and celebrate women’s contributions. To more effectively and thoroughly cover policy and research, however, earlier this month we published an additional, special issue of the magazine. This special research issue is a “first.” It is available on the SWE Magazine app, designed for mobile devices and downloadable through the App Store or Google play. To view on desktop and laptop-computers, type into your browser: http://bit.ly/SWEMagSpecialIssue A print version is also available for purchase through www.Amazon.com .The special issue was released in time for SWE’s Congressional Visits day, providing background helpful to our advocacy event. But you don’t need a special time or group activity to advocate, and the special issue pro-vides easy access to information that supports those efforts. 

A GOOD MATCH 

SWE’s special research issue contains the annual literature review, which had been a longtime staple of the spring issue, plus articles on specific research, such as SWE’s recent study, “Climate Control: Gender and Racial Bias in Engineering.” Policy issues are covered in detail, including Title IX in the United States, as well as efforts in Europe and Canada, toward greater gender equity. Con-ducting research with gender analysis as the basis is the topic of an especially interesting article on gendered innovations. The content of the special issue pairs well with the spring issue, though here we take a bit more celebratory tone. Women’s History Month takes place not only in the United States during March, but also in the United Kingdom and Australia. In Canada, October is set aside to honor women’s history, highlighted by Persons Day on Oct. 18. Inter-national Women’s Day, however, is celebrated throughout the world. In this issue you will find: • “Women Engineers You Should Know,” now an annual feature, embodies the spirit of Women’s History Month by honoring the contributions and lives of women who might otherwise go unrecognized. • “The Archives and the Archivist: Sharing SWE’s Story Together” takes an in-depth look at the rich history found in the Soci-ety’s archives, and the archivist who, for the past nine years, has carefully curated and promoted the collection. • “LGBTQ Employment Policy Caught in the Crosscurrents” is a thorough examina-tion of workplace policies, resources, and personal experiences, in the backdrop of potentially shifting social and political dynamics. • For fun, our cover story, “Engineering the Magic of Live Entertainment,” addresses the use of technology in live entertainment and the collaboration that takes place between artists, designers, and engineers. And lastly, our upfront news department offers informative content ranging from the women of NASA who are poised to shape the frontiers of space exploration, to the massive influx of women interested in running for public office. Our Voices and Views, in the back of the book, provide personal insights and perspectives. I encourage you to spend some time with both magazines. Each offers content par-ticularly relevant to women engineers, with much to absorb, reflect upon, and put to practical use. 

Director of Editorial & Publications anne.perusek@swe.org 

# A Month of Celebration and Advocacy 

TO MORE EFFEC TIVELY AND THOROUGHLY COVER POLICY AND RESEARCH, EARLIER THIS MONTH WE PUBLISHED AN ADDITIONAL, SPECIAL ISSUE OF THE MAGAZINE. THIS SPECIAL RESEARCH ISSUE IS A “FIRST.” I
